name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Friday, 18 December 2020. First of all, I would like to wish all my fellow Members a happy New Year, and I hope that everyone has had a happy holiday.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thirty years ago, on 13 January 1991, 14 civilians died and hundreds of people were injured when Soviet tanks arrived when they attacked the television tower in Vilnius.  The Lithuanians were defending their independence and freedom, they were defending democracy and the rule of law. These are our European values and today we pay tribute to those citizens who defended these values with their lives. And speaking of fundamental values, we are deeply concerned about the arrest of Alexei Navalny on his return to Moscow yesterday.  Europe saved his life and we thank the German authorities for caring for and assisting him.  We call on the Russian authorities to release Mr Navalny. His detention is a violation of human rights; We support him, and we would like him to visit us here in the European Parliament soon.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Javier Zarzalejos, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the implementation of the European arrest warrant and surrender procedures between Member States (2019/2207(INI)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, as unfortunately it is at this time, nor will 'blue card' applications be accepted.  There are also remotely intervention by Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States, as we are now accustomed to doing.

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I present to the House the report implementing the European arrest and surrender order drawn up within the LIBE Commission. We are talking about an essential instrument of judicial cooperation and, consequently, one of the foundations of the area of freedom, security and justice. The order, which was introduced by the Framework Decision of 13 July 2002, is undoubtedly the most outstanding achievement in judicial cooperation that we have achieved in the Union and has opened the way for other instruments which have since allowed this path of progress to continue. Replacing the classic extradition procedure, based on mistrust between legal systems, with a surrender procedure based on trust and mutual recognition of judgments was a real qualitative leap for the benefit of the rule of law and the reparation of victims by eliminating spaces of impunity. Throughout the discussion of this report , of which I have had the honour of being rapporteur, I stressed that the trajectory of the European arrest and surrender order is, on the whole, a remarkable success. But at the same time, we believe there is room for improvement. To explore these ways of improvement, this certainly legally complex but convenient and timely debate has been devoted. The order has raised important questions throughout its term which have been largely clarified by valuable case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union. We have strengthened this instrument of cooperation in a dual direction. On the one hand, it has clearly placed the delivery procedure within the framework of the fundamental rights and procedural safeguards which it must respect. On the other hand, it reaffirmed the cooperation obligations of the States, avoiding deviations in their application and transposition into national law of the Framework Decision, deviations away from the spirit and letter of that decision. I believe that the Commission is aware of this situation, as is apparent from the report it recently submitted, and we encourage that these deviations be corrected, also, if necessary, through the relevant infringement procedures. The report I am presenting has been built on this balance between effective cooperation and guarantees. The text is clear in proposing that the use of the order must meet criteria of proportionality and coherence with other existing and less intrusive instruments of judicial cooperation, so that, where the same result can be achieved with those instruments, they can be used. I would like to point out, in a clear and conclusive way, that the concern to incorporate a demanding guarantee framework with respect for fundamental rights is clearly present in the text and has been at the heart of our discussions. We have not circumvented the objective factors which are now affecting trust between States, but, in the line of interpretation established by the Court, we want to maintain an attitude of extraordinary prudence so as not to damage this crucial instrument of cooperation. Delivery is the general principle, and refusal to execute an order must be the exception, interpreted restrictively and duly substantiated. The report proposes to expand the current list of thirty-two offences or criminal categories that do not require double incrimination control to incorporate ten new categories ranging from certain types of tax evasion, violence against women, specific web crimes, hate crimes, acts of mass contamination, crimes against public order in the event of serious threat or use of violence or against the constitutional integrity of States involving the use of violence, as well as crimes of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. We understand that the logic of cooperation must lead to new spaces where such cooperation occurs more smoothly between States that protect essential legal goods, between states that are part of and which are recognized as members of a community of law. Precisely to make this cooperation more fluid, we do not overlook the practical aspects that advise strengthening Eurojust's role and means, as well as improving the training of legal operators, specializing national bodies that must deal with delivery procedures and also improving the information available on the implementation of the order. I would like to sincerely thank all the groups for their contributions. We have been able to discuss this issue in the best spirit, and personally I have sought to make a special effort to facilitate a comprehensive agreement that was reflected in the LIBE Commission vote at the beginning of the last December. I would like to stress in this regard that the widely agreed commitments cover the vast majority of the 235 amendments that were tabled. I hope that this consensus will continue and I also hope that those who did not join this initial agreement will be able to do so today. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, no one will deny that security and freedom — that binomial wrapped in what we call the rule of law — faces new challenges, new forms of criminality, powerful technological means used against it, new threats of violent destabilization, new forms of victimisation. The only alternative to impunity is cooperation. The best security for defending fundamental rights is precisely effective judicial cooperation against crime. This report wants to contribute to this reflection, it wants to help strengthen this cooperation with all the guarantees that are part of the legal acquis of the European Union, and for this I ask Parliament's support for the text which is proposed today.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Zarzalejos, for the work done over the past few months on this report on the European Arrest Warrant. I look forward to having the opportunity today to be here with you to discuss this essential instrument for the area of freedom, security and justice. The European Arrest Warrant is the most effective criminal justice instrument in Europe. It is an essential tool for handing over persons suspected of having committed an offence from one EU Member State to another. It ensures that suspects and convicted persons cannot escape justice within the Union.  As evidenced by the number of warrants issued and executed, as well as the considerable increase in the preliminary questions put to the Court of Justice in this area, the European Arrest Warrant is widely used by legal practitioners and the Court's jurisprudence has played a major role in strengthening a uniform application of this instrument, as well as ensuring respect for fundamental rights.  Of course, as the Commission has already pointed out in its July 2020 report, there is room for further improvement in the functioning of the arrest warrant. This is also acknowledged by the Member States, which adopted conclusions on this issue in December 2020. In your report, you also included a number of suggestions. I would like to point out, already, that the Commission has read this report with great interest, and in particular in the context of our work on improving the arrest warrant. Let me give you some concrete examples. First, on the respect of fundamental rights, I want to underline that there is no doubt that European arrest warrants need to respect our fundamental values. The system is structured on that basis. As you know, the respect of fundamental rights is underlined in the framework decision itself. Clear standards for its application have also been set by the case law of the Court of Justice. In particular, the Court has confirmed that a refusal is possible on fundamental rights grounds as regards detention conditions and the right to a fair trial, as well as in exceptional cases. Moreover, the respect of fundamental rights is also enshrined in the EU's procedural-wide directives, which have to be fully transposed and implemented in all Member States. However, our work is not limited to this observation. The Commission intends to continue to reflect on possible additional safeguards for the protection of fundamental rights. As your report noted, issues of evidence admissibility and remand are particularly relevant and require in-depth analysis. We will be conducting studies on these subjects, in order to take a closer look at the existing problems and the need for possible European rules. Let me turn to your reports' proposal: the modification of the list of offences for which no double criminality check is required. Firstly, I would like to point out that the list as it stands covers most of the offences that Member States consider serious offences within the EU. Having said that, the Commission will look into this issue through a gap analysis to see if further offences would need to be added or whether a more precise definition of the offences as mentioned in the current list is needed. As you know, the Commission is also working on an initiative to expand the list of Euro—crimes with regard to hate speech and violence against women. This will result in more common EU offences no longer requiring a double criminality check. Moreover, any possible modification of this list would not just affect the functioning of the European Arrest Warrant, but would likely also have an impact on all of the relevant material recognition instruments that contain a similar list, such as the European Investigation Order. Another point. The Commission welcomes the soft law measures recommended in your report. As you know, the Commission is already providing funding for training and networks on the European Arrest Warrant, and we intend to continue doing so. We also share your focus on the importance of reliable data. The Commission is currently inquiring about the possibilities to expand the digital actions platforms to judicial cooperation instruments such as the European Arrest Warrant. This will lead to better comparable data in the future. We agree with your focus on the importance of direct contacts and consultation between judicial authorities. I hope we can also improve the situation by a closer alignment with all relevant parties through the European Arrest Warrant coordination group that was recently set up by the Commission.  Finally, we have started revising the Handbook on the European Arrest Warrant. It will contain an update of the 33 new judgments rendered by the Court of Justice on the instruments since the last version of the handbook in 2017. Before I conclude, let me go back to one last point that I think is fundamental. The Commission attaches the utmost importance to the complete and correct transposition of the framework decision on the European Arrest Warrant. So far, we have launched infringement proceedings against seven Member States on transposition issues and we will continue, if necessary, as early as this year. We welcome the fact that some Member States are planning to amend their national legislation to address the deficiencies identified. This is essential work if we are to achieve the optimal functioning of the arrest warrant throughout the Union. I thank you for your attention and I now look forward to hearing your questions and comments on this instrument, which, I repeat, is probably the most important instrument in the functioning of our criminal justice system throughout the European Union and the cooperation, of course, of the Member States in this area.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, Commissioner, Dear Rapporteur, the European arrest warrant is one of the pillars of the Schengen area; it is a pillar for security, but also for the freedom and fundamental rights of all Europeans. There is no free movement without cooperation and no confidence in security and combating crime. But today, as I have 18 years ago, and I speak as a member of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, the mandate remains one of the best instruments of constitutional integration of our internal legal systems.  But when the age of majority is, the European arrest warrant is prepared for more. It must be conformed to the Treaty of Lisbon. We need to adapt it to the new world of crime. More harmonisation is needed. Like Schengen, also in the area of security, freedom and justice, the European arrest warrant needs a strategy for the future, a strategy that is up-to-date in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, a European area in which freedom of movement can be moved freely across borders needs tools to ensure that cross-border criminals actually go to court and do not escape their deserved punishment. The European Arrest Warrant is such an instrument. And it has proved to be a successful tool. Whereas at the beginning of this century it took an average of one year to exchange a suspect within the EU, we see that today it succeeds in an average of one and a half months. Justice is now eight times faster, and this is partly due to that European arrest warrant, a perhaps little-known but just as important part of our joint cooperation in the field of justice in the EU. It is true that the context has changed in those last 20 years. The digital transformation has also changed the nature of crime and there is therefore a need to adapt this instrument to the present day, for example by adding crimes – which have already been discussed – which have become more relevant in recent years, but also by looking carefully at detention conditions, proportionality and procedural safeguards, and – an absolute prerequisite for cooperation in this area – protection of the rule of law in all our Member States.  Yes, there are challenges to the European arrest warrant, and Mr Zarzalejos has already put it very well in his report, but it does not detract from the fact – as the report also says – that the European arrest warrant has been an extremely important tool, is today, and will continue to be indispensable in the future.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the European arrest warrant, by Government Framework Decision in 2002, was an anticipatory giant step in the area of freedom, security and justice. It overcomes the old extradition, a political decision of governments by a guaranteeing, binding and directly operational judicial procedure, which does not also require a double incrimination review on a list of thirty-two offences. Since then it has been the story of a success: 43,000 European arrest warrants have been successfully completed, reducing the times of the old extradition from two years to an average of forty or fifty days. However, the time elapsed — the enlargement of the European Union, which in 2002 had fifteen members and then went on to twenty-seven and twenty-eight – made it more complex, but also more unequal, showing, in the succession of the episodes of crisis chained up ever since, the erosion of the principles of mutual trust and mutual recognition on which precisely the space of freedom is based , security and justice enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, Article 82 of which binds all Member States. That is exactly why the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs which I chair has adopted this initiative report: exactly to examine, reassess and re-en-repulse the European arrest warrant, learning from the lessons of experience. This means addressing the need for training to implement the European detention manual, paying attention to the divergences currently between the different procedural systems and their guarantees in the Member States, harmonising European criminal law..., but also expanding the list, free of double incrimination, to deal with crimes such as gender-based violence, environmental crimes or crimes against humanity or genocide and violence against the constitutional integrity of the Member States. All this, in compliance with the principles of proportionality, necessity and minimum intervention, but above all, relaunching the European order to overcome its restrictive refusal, which prohibits the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, and ensuring that in no case does the guarantee of fundamental rights cover up an examination by the requested State of the quality of the judicial organisation or the competence of the states required in judicial matters. If this initiative is approved, as we expect, in this European Parliament, it will be up to the Commission to adopt the legislative initiative. Because that is what an initiative report is all about: linking the Commission to bring an update that provides for a European code of criminal justice cooperation.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today is one of those days when we can feel the usefulness of this Parliament. We started the legislature with a clear idea: the European arrest warrant needed to be revised to minimise, to improve, of course to avoid impunity in the Schengen area, to better protect victims of crime in the European Union and also to improve the guarantees of people involved in crime. Thanks to loyal collaboration between the large political groups in this house, we have an implementation report that clearly shows us the blind angles of this cornerstone of judicial cooperation in the European Union, the Euroorder. Minimizing, as I say, impunity in the Schengen area is key. And it also means adapting judicial cooperation to the new times, to the digital revolution, to threats, to new threats to the rule of law. Because the world changes and our rules must improve with those changes, with those mutations also of crime. So we are committed to a mechanism with greater proportionality, which means not using the instrument in misdemeanors, but at the same time being effective in prosecuting the most serious crimes, such as threats to public order in the Member States and crimes against constitutional integrity committed with the use of violence , not forgetting other crimes against humanity, genocide and war crimes. As legislators, we must move forward in improving this mechanism and have my personal commitment not to stop working for it.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Andrew Symeou is a British citizen accused of being involved in the death of a man in Greece and handed over to the Greek justice system by European arrest warrant in July 2009. He then spent ten months in dire conditions of detention and was prevented from returning home until July 2011, when he was exonerated. Two years of a life wasted, away from his loved ones and with a violent interruption of his studies. If this case is emblematic and a little more known than the others, it is not isolated. The consequences on people's lives are dramatic. It is difficult to have figures on these abuses that are due to multiple reasons: disproportionate use for minor offenses, non-compliance with fundamental rights or mere normal police error that a remote hearing could have demonstrated. However, the European Arrest Warrant is an indispensable tool for the development of this judicial cooperation which guarantees a true European Union, and it avoids many problems related to conventional extradition. That is why we must evaluate it with the utmost seriousness and sincerity.  The proper functioning of the tools of cooperation is based on the principle of mutual recognition and implies mutual trust in the legal systems of the Member States, but the deterioration of the rule of law and freedoms in our Union no longer encourages blind trust. In some cases, the independence of the judiciary is weakened, as in Hungary. It is even questioned in Poland.  Today, the immense responsibility lies with the judge concerned by the request to decide whether or not to extradite a person to a Member State, where his rights may not be respected, without genuine European support or resources available to him to investigate and justify his refusal. The European Parliament must therefore send a strong signal that the application of the mandate is accompanied by strong procedural guarantees, both in the issuing state and in the implementing state. Above all, we must guard against any political instrumentalisation of these tools and, in this matter, we deplore a small lack of hindsight, sometimes, of some European parliamentarians, and the importance that Spain's national interests have taken at the expense of a global watchful eye.  It is proposed to add the mention of a country's crime against the constitutional integrity of a country to the list of offences that do not require verification or debate. This opens a terribly dangerous gap. Such a provision would endanger many political activists in the European Union, the notion of constitutional integrity being able to lead to so many interpretations, our Constitutions are so different. We cannot allow conflicts of interest in a Member State to have a police impact on an entire European process.  The European Arrest Warrant can be a very effective and positive tool for victims, for a European Union that guarantees rights and for confronting mafias, major crimes, violence and terrorism. But it must be used wisely, with vigilance and proportionality. National justices must be formed, alternative procedures used, fundamental rights respected, interpretation ensured in proceedings, and improved conditions of detention.  We thank the rapporteur for including our proposals on fundamental rights and we thank the Commissioner for recalling the necessary changes and the necessary conditions of justice.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The motion for a European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the European arrest warrant and the procedures for issuing persons between Member States submitted for discussion is not in any major doubt, and its content focuses on suggestions to both the European Commission and the Member States to improve EAW procedures and apply them even more effectively.  The resolution also calls for a cross-cutting analysis of mutual recognition instruments in order to prevent divergences and ensure their coordination. A holistic approach to the whole system of mutual recognition in criminal matters is essential to ensure its coherence, as has been repeatedly highlighted.  However, in view of the generally positive assessment of the EAW contained in the first part of the resolution, it does not seem entirely and incomprehensible to suggest that amendments to the Decision should be considered, mainly as regards the waiver of the double criminality test. Soft law measures, such as manuals of procedures and recommendations, are also a more appropriate way of improving the application of the EAW, and focusing on the practical aspects of the functioning of the instrument, including, in particular, the continuous training and competence of persons who use EU criminal law instruments in their professional practice.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, I think there are some really positive elements in this report. We welcome the call to strengthen procedural safeguards, rule of law and fundamental rights in judicial cooperation. We’re very glad to see the call for less intrusive instruments instead of the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) and the EAW only being used as a last resort. We’re glad to see the call for the equality of arms between prosecution and defence, which has long been sought, and we’re very glad to see the call for the Commission to promote and facilitate access to training for criminal lawyers. So why, in God’s name, are we trying to undermine that good work by the politicisation of this report by elements in this Parliament opposed to Catalan independence? Is there no end to this really? Unhappy with the fact that Catalan politicians were not extradited from Belgium or from Germany because the crimes that they were supposedly responsible for are actually not crimes at all under the double criminality clause in those countries, and instead of seeing that now and making sure that doesn’t happen again, we see in this report the call for offences against public order and constitutional integrity to be exempt from double criminality. We cannot accept that. Have you not learned from history? You cannot suppress a movement by repressive measures, and fundamental rights apply to everybody – even Catalans – and you should remember that. And last, but not least, I think it would be wrong not to mention Julian Assange in the context of a debate on extradition, still in prison for journalism, for exposing US war crimes. He’s done humanity a great service. I call on Joe Biden to free him now.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the strengthening of the common area of freedom, security and justice in the European Union cannot be separated from improving the implementation of the European Arrest Warrant, one of the main instruments for combating serious cross-border crime. There are a number of issues that need to be addressed in order to improve their functioning, including those relating to prison and prison conditions, the training of operators, the lack of a comprehensive data system, the extension of categories of crime for which double criminality verification is not required. The current pandemic has also highlighted the central role played by digitalisation in judicial cooperation in criminal matters. And therefore, the timely transposition and application of the EEA framework decision and the directives on procedural guarantees, taking into account the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, are the duty of the Member States and are essential to bring the perpetrators of crimes to justice while respecting fundamental rights and the rule of law, as well as to increase mutual trust in national criminal justice systems.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Madam President! No criminal should be able to hide in one EU country for another EU country. This has been the case for many years, and Denmark has been part of the agreement that secures it since 2004. We are now debating and voting on the report, which assesses the functioning of the cooperation agreement between EU countries and moves forward. But it needs to get up to speed, because we still see major challenges with cross-border crime. It is, of course, good for criminals, but it is really bad for the legal awareness of law-abiding citizens and the confidence that the 'rule of law' thing we are actually able to work out together. Of course, the far left in this House has tried to water down the report's points and, unsurprisingly, they are voting against it. It is shameful – for many good reasons. Among other things, the report strikes a major blow for cross-border cooperation against crime to be extended to include corruption, trafficking in human beings, gender-related violence and cybercrime. But the far left will not work for that. Understand it, who can, I can't! And I hope that many colleagues will now support sending criminals a strong signal that here in the European Union you have to behave properly and you cannot hide from the long arm of the law. While this cooperation is being reviewed, I will personally work positively for Denmark to remove its opt-out from judicial cooperation, because no criminal should be able to hide in Denmark or for Denmark – no one!

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European arrest warrant is the basis for judicial cooperation in the European Union and is based on mutual trust, trust in the rule of law. In 2018, an Irish judge refused to execute an order issued in Poland. Reason? In Poland, the rule of law is under threat. The fight for the systemic rule of law has thus covered the EU's ordinary courts. It is good that we are more and more in this fight, but it is also proof that the EU institutions are doing too little.  Polish Judge Igor Tuleya spoke about it recently with great sadness. The erosion of the rule of law is the destruction of cooperation under the European arrest warrant, it is the destruction of trust in the European project, which is now very high, but it is not given once and for all. The citizens of the Union did not deserve the institutions to do too little. This is about their rights, about the guarantees of these rights, so I am turning to the Commission, the Council, all of us: It is time to act. Now or it will be too late.

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner Didier Reynders, in Europe the fight against terrorism and crime must not know any borders. Created in 2002 in the wake of the September 11 attacks, the European Arrest Warrant has proven to be an effective instrument, far more reliable and fast than the traditional extradition procedure. Between 2005 and 2016, 43,000 European arrest warrants were executed.  I would like to return to three priorities of my Renew group, defended alongside my colleague Maite Pagazaurtunda. Ensure a regular review of outstanding arrest warrants to compensate for blocking situations. Strengthen the European budget of the European Judicial Cooperation Agency Eurojust, which contributes to good cooperation between national judicial authorities. Finally, create a common database at EU level to list current and executed European arrest warrants. These proposals are to improve, as you said Mr Reynders, one of the most concrete tools at European level to ensure the protection and security of our citizens, for a Europe of justice and security.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Reynders, the Euroorder is a mechanism that operates under the principles of mutual trust between States and respect for fundamental rights. But mutual trust cannot be confused with blind trust, as there are still European countries with obvious judicial deficiencies. That is why today's debate should focus on how to strengthen procedural safeguards, not how to expressly stop. Ladies and gentlemen, this house cannot open debates or propose reforms of mechanisms just to satisfy the repressive pulses of some. We are playing the credibility of this Parliament. Adding the crime of constitutional integrity to the list of direct extradition offences will not facilitate the detention of Catalan leaders, but will open the door to unfair or arbitrary extraditions for those states with little status by European values of justice and freedom.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Madam President, the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) is a valuable cross-border tool in the fight against terrorism and serious crime. The speed of extradition now, compared to the cumbersome processes of the past, is greatly improved. However, many will remember a time when this House repeatedly expressed concern regarding its use for petty crimes, or the system errors which destroyed the lives of unlucky individuals. This Parliament pushed therefore for actions and consequently its implementation has greatly been improved. Yet we were recently reminded of the pitfalls when the Spanish Government used the EAW for its own political agenda. It reminded us that instruments can be used, abused and stretched if there isn’t careful monitoring and protection in place. Rather than seeking to create new powers and widening the scope of the EAW, we must first build back trust between the Member States and increase transparency and judicial independence. This is the only way we can help.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Madam President, we all know what this remarkable interest of the Spanish MEPs in the European Arrest Warrant is about. It’s about their frustration because judges in several Member States have refused to execute politically motivated arrest warrants against us, the Catalan exiles. Yes, Germany and Belgium have refused extradition requests. Their courts told the Spanish Supreme Court that they have used the European Arrest Warrant because they prosecute inexistent crimes and they disregard fundamental rights. In Brussels a court of appeal has ruled that the presumption of innocence isn’t guaranteed in Spain, and they noted that Spain disobeys the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detentions. When a court of appeal rules that the Spanish Supreme Court cannot be trusted for a fair trial, the problem is not in the regulation of European arrest warrants – the problem is the political contamination of justice in Spain and that, Mr Reynders, is your business. It’s not an internal affair. It’s not an internal affair, Mr Reynders. You should take care of the rule of law in Spain.

name: Evin INCIR
text: – Madam President, the EU is not only an economic union; more than that it is a people’s union. The safety of our citizens must be of primary concern. The freedom of movement should also be supplemented with strong cooperation across the borders to prevent any kind of impunity. That is why the cooperation on criminal matters is of particular importance. By sharing information and by creating common instruments to facilitate our cooperation, we are taking steps towards effectively addressing issues such as terrorism and organised crime, but also gender-based violence and hate crimes. However, I also want to stress that some issues are of national competence as procedural issues, such as admissibility of evidence. It is important that the European Arrest Warrant contributes to streamlining the struggle against crime, not making it more complicated. Of course, with that said, respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights always needs to be in the centre, and safeguards always need to be in place. The arrest warrant must be up to date for a better cooperation and therefore also a safer Europe for all citizens. As the rapporteur said, security and freedom go hand in hand.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, it’s good that we have an efficient instrument. It is also true that if we look at the numbers between 2005 and 2017 (raw numbers) – and I’m aware of the explanations of the Commission – we have less than one-third of European warrants being executed. And this makes me wonder whether we should look, first of all of course, at updating this instrument and then secondly, looking at true cooperation and enforcement of this instrument, and also at the obligation of the Member States to respect their commitment and to respect European legislation. We have situations with regard to efficiency as well. I’m from a country where the handing-over procedure is the fastest in the Union: 11 days. But there are also countries where this procedure takes up to 90 days, and this doubles the European average. And then we also have countries which refuse to cooperate and which refuse to implement it. It would be a pity to hide each other’s criminals and it will be a pity not to use efficiently this instrument in full cooperation and with respect for European law.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the need to reform and improve the Council Framework Decision governing the Euroorder is of vital importance, an incontestable fact also for this group. Membership of the European Union implies respect for the rights and guarantees set out in Article 2 of the Treaty and, therefore, the withdrawal of border controls from the Schengen area cannot serve to ensure that criminals by economic means seek for desirability forums to evade justice in the Member States and avoid what happened in 2018 , in which of 17 000 Euro-orders issued, only 7 000 were executed. This is the case, for example, of the terrorist Natividad Jáuregui, claimed by the Spanish judges for the assassination of Lieutenant Colonel Ramón Romeo, who spent seventeen years in Belgium without the Belgian courts accepting a decision of the Spanish courts. Despite the urgency and dimension of the problem, this own-initiative report suffers from warmness and ideological content, since, while recognising the fundamental principle of mutual recognition of judgments, it opens up numerous spis and avenues to prevent the application of them. It goes to the abusive instrument of the rule of law mechanism, which has nothing to do with it. Here we are. Either we respect the laws adopted by the Member States in national parliaments or we respect the position of criminals who intend to take care of the same as convenience forums. That is why we must say from the European Parliament that crimes against the integrity and constitutional order of the Member States are crimes in any case, without requiring violence. Nor do we think it appropriate that issues of ideological content, such as crimes of opinion, be included in this reform of the Euroorder under the figure of hate crime or even the disputed figure of gender-based violence offences. In my party, for all this, and out of respect for the victims in all cases, we will decide to abstain in this Decision and request that the Commission technically improve this document, in order to ensure the judicial sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, first of all, thank you very much to the rapporteur, to Mr Zarzalejos. Congratulations on this very good report, for which I will vote in favour, as a whole of my group. I'm going to focus on two important aspects. First, the extension of the list of offences, absolutely necessary. Mrs Delbos-Corfield, I have misunderstood whether you are opposed to extending the list in general or only as regards offences against constitutional integrity. But, of course, I know that your group defends federal Europe and federalization. How can you be against expanding the list of hate crimes, genocide, environmental crimes or the crime against constitutional integrity itself? It is no crime joke what Mr Puigdemont or Mrs Ponsatí did, who has intervened before. It's no joke to unilaterally declare independence.  You know how World War II began: unilaterally altering a border. You've seen what happened at the Capitol. Do you think it's a joke, really, to attack the constitutional order?

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, nothing has hurt Spain's image in Europe more than seeing criminals, including politicians, walking around Belgium with impunity. Europe cannot survive without maintaining basic trust between countries. It is not possible to have a space of free movement that leads to impunity for criminals. In recent weeks, the president of the United States has been trying to subvert the constitutional order to defend democracy. Can you imagine that those who stormed Congress could stay in Texas and the Texas courts simply refuse to let these people face the criminal consequences of their actions? Nothing, no one, let alone public representatives are above the law. That is why the European Parliament is now making a reform proposal which includes offences against the constitutional order. I hope that the Commission, Mr Reynders, will now follow the path set by Parliament and that we will end this damaging impunity.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Crime is becoming increasingly limitless, coordinated and advanced. Gang crime is on the rise. There are more fatal shootings. We need more European cooperation to combat crime.  An important step is the European arrest warrant, which has now been in place for many years. With it, we can stop serious criminals from hiding from the law and abusing freedom of movement. However, if it is to work, the Member States must rely on each other's legal certainty and that is not the case today. Poland has restricted the rule of law to the point that other Member States no longer consider it a legally secure country to extradite people to and more Member States are heading in the same direction.  This resolution shows how important the European arrest warrant is for law enforcement in Europe. But it also makes it clear that respect for the rule of law and its independence is absolutely crucial to judicial cooperation in the EU.  The road to security in Europe is not through closed borders, but through stronger cooperation based on fundamental values of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Vlad GHEORGHE
text: – Mr President, the last year has once again shown how strong a united Europe is, but it cannot exist without a united justice, without strong justice. A unified justice allows for greater security for European citizens, stability and a solid ground for the values we all share.  The European arrest warrant must therefore be strengthened and updated. We can no longer allow criminals to find refuge in some of the Member States. We can no longer allow the just punishment to be delayed or delayed for political reasons. It is time to be united in the fight against digital crime and the environment in particular. We need to strongly condemn gender-based violence and hate crimes.  From tax evasion to crimes against humanity, judicial cooperation helps us build a safer Europe for us and our children. Commissioner, I ask you to jointly support an improved European arrest warrant, enabling justice to be carried out without delay in all the Member States of our great European family.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, thank you to the services for this tireless work so that we can speak here in your House.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank you for your speeches during this debate. It seems to me, of course, with nuances, that there is a broad consensus on the usefulness of the European Arrest Warrant within the area of freedom and security, particularly for practitioners in the field. It must be remembered that this is really a tool at the heart of this discussion on freedom and security but also justice, I would remind you as the Commissioner responsible.  Perhaps I would like to clarify the framework in which we are involved with practitioners. The arrest warrant procedure is a purely judicial proceeding, and though the Commission can help practitioners with technical expertise, it has no jurisdiction to intervene in the manner in which Member States administer justice in individual cases. The framework decision allows the executing authorities to refuse execution of the arrest warrant in certain cases, in particular for offences other than those covered by the list of 32 crimes for which there is no double criminality check. The executing state may decide a surrender will be subject to the condition that the acts at stake equally constitute an offence under its national law. Thus the outcome of a double criminality assessment may be different from one Member State to another, depending on whether the charge as determined by the issuing state would constitute a criminal offence in the executing state and whether that Member State decided to make use of its discretionary power to invoke this ground for refusal. And the Commission will, of course, as I said, continue its work to ensure that the European Arrest Warrant is properly implemented in all Member States. We have already introduced infringement procedures and, if necessary, we will introduce more. I also note that you share the Commission's desire to improve certain shortcomings in the functioning of the European Arrest Warrant, notably through training, networking of different actors and the adoption of certain non-legislative measures. This is certainly something we are working on and will continue to work together.  We need to improve judicial cooperation, particularly through this tool, but also through other instruments that we will still have the opportunity to discuss, especially in a judicial world that is moving towards an increasingly digital transition.  And, in this context, we will also continue to work to protect, as I have pointed out, fundamental rights. The European Court of Justice is helping us in this area, particularly through its case law, which we will include in a manual for practitioners. It is important that this protection of fundamental rights is also at the heart of the debate on the European Arrest Warrant.  I would like to end by saying, of course, because many have mentioned it, that we will also continue to use all the instruments at our disposal to ensure the rule of law within the European Union, across all member states. But, again, the tool we have before us today is a very effective tool for judicial cooperation. It is up to us to make it work as well as possible and to improve it, if we have the opportunity.
