name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: in writing. – I would like to congratulate the rapporteur of this report, my colleague Javier Zarzalejos, on the work he has done. The Euroorder is based on trust between Member States. We must adapt the Euro-order so that fugitive offenders in a Member State cannot hide within the European Union without being tried for the offences against them. With this initiative we send from the European Parliament a clear message to the European Commission, which has the legislative initiative, on the need to reform the Euroorder. In particular, we call for the inclusion of a number of new offences, in particular offences against the public order of the Member States, where they are a serious threat or contemplate violence, and crimes against the constitutional integrity of States using violence. From here we call on the European Commission to turn this message into a legislative initiative.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the presentation of the Court of Auditors' 2019 Annual Report (2019/2866 (RSP)." We welcome the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Klaus-Heiner Lehne. I would remind Members once again that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session, that no blue cards are accepted and that, if necessary, we have also provided for interconnections from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: Mr President of the Court of Auditors. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Hahn, representatives of the Presidency, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are living in extremely difficult times. As always in the European Union, however, major crises often lead to major steps forward and to innovations that would have been considered impossible only a few months earlier. Thanks also to the perseverance of this Parliament, the major decisions and agreements that will be crucial for EU finances over the next seven years have been finalised in good time. I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate the then Presidency and the Commission on the results. We can now look forward to the Member States' ratification of the own resources decision, which I hope will be swift. I am pleased to be here with you today, together with my colleague Tony Murphy, the Member of the Court responsible for the annual report, to present and discuss the Court's annual report for 2019. Due to the particular circumstances of the current COVID-19 crisis, this year's presentation of the annual report will take place a little later than usual. Perhaps this is even an advantage, since the Committee on Budgetary Control has now made further progress with its work on discharge. The lessons you have all gained in recent weeks in the course of the various hearings can thus already be incorporated into today's debate, and I do not think that is a bad thing. It is particularly important that the political decisions you make in this House or that you agree with are translated into results on the ground and that you can assess what went well and what has not and how things can be improved. That is what our detailed and independent audits that we have presented to you are all about. In the meantime, our findings for 2019 are probably widely known. We continue to give an unqualified opinion on both the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of revenue. In terms of expenditure, the overall error rate we estimate has remained stable – 2.7% in 2019, compared with an estimated 2.6% in 2018. This overall rate, of course, masks the considerable differences that exist between the various policy areas. In the area of competitiveness, the error rate we estimate has increased to 4%, mainly due to ineligible costs. However, the improvements observed in the field of natural resources reduced the estimated error rate to 1.9%, i.e. also below materiality. In the area of administration, as in previous years, we did not determine a significant error rate. In the area of cohesion, we estimate that the error rate, taking into account the corrections made by the authorities of the Member States, is 4.4%, which is lower than in the previous year, but still substantial. Moreover, if the national authorities and the Commission succeed in remedying the shortcomings in the error rates they estimate in the next few years, we may well be able to make greater use of the work of the member states' audit authorities. But it is not so far. I know that the Commission is determined to achieve this objective, but a great deal of effort is still needed at all levels to achieve this in the end. For several years, we have distinguished between expenditure, which we believe involves a high level of risk – such as cohesion expenditure, where management is shared with the Member States – and expenditure of a different kind, where we consider the risk to be low. Expenditure associated with high risk has a significant error rate of an estimated 4.9%, compared with 4.5% in the previous year. What happened in 2019, however, was an increase in the proportion of high-risk expenditure, particularly in the cohesion sector, to 53%. This is not a problem in itself, because cohesion expenditure is usually very useful.  The fact is, however, that the majority of our audit population now has a significant error rate – so the error rate is comprehensive according to our audit understanding. That is why the Court of Auditors has issued a failed audit opinion on expenditure for the financial year 2019 and not, as in previous years, a limited opinion. This is not to be understood as a kind of recrimination directed solely at the Commission – after all, the authorities of the Member States manage around 74% of the Union's expenditure. Each body has a role in the chain, and excessive simplification, as we all know, is ultimately also no solution. However, this should not be seen as a general step backwards in EU financial management. Compared to the situation 10 or even 20 years ago, we have achieved an enormous amount. Moreover, in addition to the overall statement for 2019, our conclusions for the various areas of expenditure are very different. I know that, as part of your work, particularly in the technical committee, you are paying attention to these areas as you prepare Parliament's discharge decision. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Let me address three overarching questions that we will face in the future. Firstly, instead of the debate in this House later this week on the nomination procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which is important, i would rather have seen the European Public Prosecutor's Office actively in its work and see how it is proceeding with real bite in order to protect the European Union's financial interests against irregularities and fraud as if they were national financial interests. It is high time that this authority was finally put on the road and provided with adequate resources, and I am aware of the firm determination of the Prosecutor General and the European Parliament to make this a reality at long last. The Court of Auditors is, of course, keen to support these efforts as much as possible, in accordance with its audit mandate. Secondly, we note that reference is made to the Court's reports as a possible source of information, based on the qualitative assessments carried out by the Commission under Regulation 2020/2092 on a general conditionality regime for the protection of the Union budget. By recognising the obvious, namely that 'there is a clear link between respect for the rule of law and the efficient implementation of the Union budget in accordance with the principle of sound financial management', the EU legislator has drawn a clear line, the implementation of which must now be enforced in practice if necessary. I welcome the fact that several of our recommendations have been taken into account during the legislative process, in particular the position of final beneficiaries or beneficiaries of European funds. Thirdly, we have repeatedly pointed out in our reports that many Member States still have considerable difficulties in making use of the EU funds they are entitled to, regardless of the objectives or requirements set at political level. This has again contributed to a large increase in outstanding commitments, amounting to EUR 298 billion at the end of 2019. As a result, these funds still have to be used for the good purposes intended by the legislator. This problem of delays in expenditure must be addressed as a matter of urgency by the Member States concerned. Let me also take the opportunity of our debate to make two more practical and forward-looking comments. With the start of NextGenerationEU, EU spending will almost double in the coming years. We discussed this in the Committee on Budgetary Control in November, when I last spoke here. I wanted to inform you that we are currently examining what this means for us as auditors in terms of tasks and the resources required. It is clear that there will be an impact on the necessary staffing levels, and I hope to be able to provide you with up-to-date information on this shortly. Finally, I would like to refer to the Court's pilot project, its 'Report on the performance of the EU budget – at the end of 2019', which responds to the desire of many in this House to focus more on the performance of the European budget and the assessment of the Commission's information in this regard. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to conclude by saying that, in these times of crisis, the Member States and the Commission have an enormous responsibility for sound and economic management of European finances. Our annual report, which I am presenting here today, makes it clear that further efforts are needed. As directly elected Members of Parliament, you have a great responsibility in the exercise of your legislative and political control function, so that this is also successful.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, dear President of the European Court of Auditors, dear Tony Murphy, ladies and gentlemen, first I would like to thank President Lehne for his presentation and for the work the Court of Auditors has undertaken to prepare its 2019 annual report. The European Union budget makes an important contribution to our common priorities for Europe. The Commission is pleased that the Court has expressed a clean opinion on the accounts for the 13th year in a row and on the revenue side of the budget. On the expenditure side, the Commission is also pleased that there are positive evolutions. The estimated levels of error for the chapters on administrative expenditure and natural resources are altogether around 55% of expenditure audited by the Court, below the Court’s 2% materiality threshold. The Commission also positively notes that the error rates for the two main blocs of EU expenditure – natural resources and cohesion – decreased compared to last year. Overall, the level of error for the EU budget as a whole remains stable: 2.7% compared to 2.6 of the previous year. The Commission carefully monitors the implementation of the Union budget on the ground in order to identify weaknesses and implement the necessary remedial actions. To do this, it has set up multiannual control systems and strives to ensure that, once a programme is closed after all controls and corrections have been carried out, the remaining level of error stays below 2%. The Commission estimated that this risk, which we call risk closure, is below 1% – 0.7, to be precise – for 2019 expenditure. According to the Commission’s own conclusion, as a manager of the European Union budget, we consider that in 2019, as in previous years, internal control systems were working effectively. Inevitably our more detailed assessment leads to slightly different results than the Court. To put it simply, the Court has a specific mandate and assesses what happens within a year. If you allow me a cinematic reference, the Court takes a snapshot; the Commission makes a movie, and while the snapshot is an integral part of the movie, it does not tell you the whole story. However, the findings and recommendations of the Court, together with ours, do help us to improve further our control systems. Simplification and better controls – not more controls – are key for the future. The Commission also gives the highest priority to the performance of spending. It’s absolutely crucial not only to do things right, but also to do the right thing: that is, to use the funds to achieve the objectives and deliver concrete results for the citizens. In conclusion, I would like to underline that more than ever, we collectively need to strike the right balance between a low level of errors, fast payments, reasonable costs of controls for public authorities and beneficiaries, and, of course, added value. The finalisation of the legal basis for the spending programmes of the new period, including the Next Generation EU, gives us the new opportunity to do so. In this context, the Commission had, for instance, proposed an obligatory use by Member States of a tool which would have allowed to collect and compare information on recipients of Union funding. This proposal has, however, not been retained in the final agreements by the co-legislators. But I would like to use the opportunity to thank in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) and its members for their tireless efforts to achieve this – but finally, unfortunately, it was not possible. Nevertheless, the Commission will nonetheless do its best to encourage Member States to use this mechanism, and it was confirmed also by the Court that this is definitely a potential improvement our for reporting system and therefore also for the quality of our assessments – both of the Court and the Commission, but also the national authorities. Once again, thank you for all your efforts and I’m looking forward to the discussion.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Lehne, Commissioner Hahn, first of all I would like to thank the European Court of Auditors for the very important work you do every year with this report. As rapporteur for Parliament's discharge report, I am pleased to say that parliament's administrative expenditure again this year had an error rate below the essential limit. But there are problems, too. All EU spending must be based on simple and clear rules. However, this is not the case at the moment. When you look at the errors found by the Court of Auditors with regard to the contributions received by one Political Party at European level, it is totally inappropriate for a European party to be unable to produce written agreements or receipts for expenditure paid with taxpayers' money. This undermines public confidence in decision-makers, which is vital to the functioning of democracy. It is incomprehensible that the Court of Auditors should have to make a recommendation on this matter year after year over and over again.  Citizens' credit to the political system will be strengthened or weakened at all levels of activity. That is why we must ensure that, when the rules for Political Parties at European level are opened up during this year, ambiguities and contradictions will be removed, which are unfortunately reflected at the level of practical action at the moment.

name: Tsvetelina PENKOVA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank President Lehne and Commissioner Hahn and Mr Murphy for being here and for their presentation. I very much welcome the report on the performance of the EU budget and the work of the Court, especially the part that strongly emphasises the outcome and the results achieved following the implementation of the EU budget, which has been one of the main priorities of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) and Parliament in previous discharges. So we welcome that fact. It is also positive to know that the report concludes that the revenue for 2019 is legal, regular and free of material error. The acknowledgment that there is a significant improvement in the EU’s spending is also encouraging.  However, it is not positive that this year the Court is giving an adverse opinion in terms of expenditure and it sees a deterioration compared with the previous three years. It is also quite surprising that the highest error rates are in competition and research and not in cohesion, which is usually the case. Cohesion remains one of the areas where the risk of error rate is highest.  In the context of the previous discharge procedures, it is important that our priority remains to learn from the previous implementation of the MFF in the various programmes. The aim in the future shouldn’t only be the implementation of the budget, but also the achievement of the results. It is important to draw the appropriate conclusions and to take adequate measures in order to continue limiting the errors in EU spending.  Also, in the context of the unforeseen pandemic, I would like to conclude by welcoming the fact that, just a few hours ago, the European Court of Auditors (ECA) published a review of the EU’s initial contribution to the public health response to COVID—19. We are looking forward to seeing the findings.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, I would of course like to thank the Court of Auditors for its work. Its independence and rigour make it the best ally of the citizens of Europe and therefore of our Parliament, the European Parliament. And this year, for the first time, we received a report dedicated to performance.  This was a priority of my Group Renew Europe. It is indeed one thing to have accounts without irregularities or even errors, yet it is necessary that the means be effectively invested in economically promising projects or policies with important leverage for the development of our values. Every euro spent must be spent efficiently. Commissioner, some of the comments would merit more attention from the Commission, given the new budgetary programme and Next Generation EU with 750 billion. In particular, I remain concerned about the very low absorption capacity of many states. Only 9 out of 27 states have better absorption capacity compared to 2012. The European average is just 40%. How can we revive our economy with such low numbers? What is the point of identifying resources if states are not able to use that money? Moreover, and unsurprisingly, errors are mainly seen in high-risk spending areas, such as rural development, innovation and cohesion. To reduce these errors, the solutions are known: simplification of administrative rules, digitisation of procedures, technical assistance and training of government officials and candidates. In this area too, the Union must make progress.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, President Lehne, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has said. Thank you for the court's two extensive reports. I have to say they really have it in them. I suspect that Commissioner Hahn had to swallow when he saw the failed opinion on expenditure. But that's the good thing - that's the only way financial control works. It must hurt. As rapporteur for the discharge of the Commission in 2019, I am, of course, particularly interested in, and indeed absolutely dependent on, the reports. And I am very grateful for the clear structure. This makes it easier for me to write my report. However, I do not want to talk about your reports today, as we have already done very often and very fundamentally and thoroughly in the CONT Committee. I would like to draw attention to a particular problem: I have the impression that the Court of Auditors is respected in Parliament, but does not receive the support necessary for its performance of its tasks. I am afraid that too many of us are concerned with considering what we need more own resources for or what programme we could put in place. In my view, it would be much more important to consider how we should be more careful and more economical with taxpayers' money. In fact, the whole parliament should be a supervisory authority. However, we prefer to postpone this task to the few colleagues who are here in the CONT Committee – they are all super committed, and they will do so. Ladies and gentlemen throughout the European Parliament, can I introduce you to this small but effective committee? He is one of the most diligent. Please equip it so that it can carry out its extensive control tasks better. Dear Commission, give us access to all the information relevant to the budget, including DG SANTE. And then, ladies and gentlemen, please strengthen the Court of Auditors with staff and material resources – as the President mentioned – as well as with the mandate for a comprehensive audit law at the EIB. We cannot increase the budget by 85% and adopt six new own resources and then hope that the Court of Auditors will be able to cope with this with the existing staff! Only those who want less control can want this. Let us respect not only the good work of the Court, no, let us strengthen it and ensure that it is not a knight without a sword, but an effective weapon in the fight to protect the EU's financial interests. I am sure it is not only President Lehne who will be pleased about this.

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Lehne, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is a very Thank you very much for your presentation. I would like to draw your attention to three aspects: firstly, the fact that there is now finally a performance report, secondly, the relatively high error rates in parts of the EU budget and, thirdly, the historic high level of outstanding commitments to be made, in the case of the backlog. We MEPs need the most precise picture possible of the actual performance of EU spending. And this has now been significantly improved by the coherent performance report – this should also be mentioned here. At the same time, the reliability and completeness of the data handed down from many countries need to be improved. The European Court of Auditors, together with the Commission, should press for reliable data from capital cities in order to be able to make truly verifiable statements on the overall performance of EU expenditure. Secondly, in selected areas such as cohesion and competitiveness, error rates are still too high. The deviations of the ECA audit reports from the Commission's own data are also striking here. It is essential to improve the internal control system here. A brief change: For a long time now, her House has been clearly critical of the effectiveness of agricultural policy. The largest EU expenditure item still lacks the necessary effectiveness. The billions of payments are not spent in a targeted manner on biodiversity, climate protection or animal welfare. However, the requirements of the European Green Deal mean that EU funds urgently need to be used more effectively in order to meet climate protection targets. Thirdly, the historical backlog. We are now talking about almost EUR 300 billion, which the Commission will have to make available in the next MFF. Of concern is not only the absolute large sum, but also the fact that the funds of the commitments entered into are significantly higher than those for payments, which could lead to the Commission becoming insolvent. In this context, the new MFF urgently needs to increase the speed of disbursement in order to improve the absorption rate, especially for the structural and investment funds.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Thank you for your kind words to the Committee on Budgetary Control, where I have been the coordinator of my political group for eleven years.  The Court's annual report provides a fair view of the situation in the EU institutions. On the other hand, it should be stressed that payments were too error-driven, mainly in a category classified as high-risk expenditure, hence the negative opinion on expenditure. And high-risk spending in 2019 accounts for more than half of spending (53%) audited.  Every year we have an increase in irregularities in EU spending. This is not some revolutionary increase – by 0.2%, 0.1% per year – but it is a fact. It is now necessary to manage the covid financial package very efficiently, as EU spending will double in the coming years.

name: Sabrina PIGNEDOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in its report on the financial year 2019, the European Court of Auditors certifies that the Eu ropean Union's accounts reflect its financial situation in a 'faithful and truthful' manner. However, it points to too many errors in expenditure deemed to be 'high-risk', which accounts for more than half of the expenditure audited: these are mainly reimbursements, for example in the areas of cohesion and rural development, which are managed by individual countries. For the Court of Auditors, the Member States are absorbing the Structural and Investment Funds too slowly. By the end of 2019, only 40 % of the European funding set for 2014-2020 had been disbursed. Improving on this issue is crucial for the period 2021-2027, especially after the agreement on Next Generation EU, with extraordinary measures to deal with the impact of the pandemic. We must resolve the issues, including with the help of individual governments, in order to make the European Union's expenditure more efficient and more useful to its citizens.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has In 2019, after the regular audit, we will also have a so-called performance audit for the first time. I would like to ask quite openly: can political results be assessed in a neutral way at all? I think: No. The criteria are stretchable, even susceptible to manipulation, and even the Court doubts the reliability of the data partly supplied by the Commission.  In general, the Court is becoming increasingly dependent on the Commission's data. I think this is a worrying development – after all, the Court of Auditors should review the Commission. I also believe that the Court of Auditors should concentrate on its core tasks, rather than performance: proper and lawful use of the funds. There really is more than enough to do here. Mr Lehne mentioned it: EUR 298 billion. We have far too many mistakes in the cohesion programmes and in the second pillar of agricultural policy. This is where we should start: more staff for the review directly in the Member States. And it is not only the Court, but also the Commission, that needs to look much more closely at the administrations. Now comes the Corona build-up program. This means that the audit effort will double. To be clear, if we want to fulfil our responsibility for monitoring, the Court of Auditors needs more capacity, as Klaus-Heiner Lehne rightly says. But then we also need a completely different – a new – role for budgetary control in our Parliament. We owe that to European taxpayers.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, thank you to the Court of Auditors for its reports, which are essential for our work on budgetary control and the protection of the financial interests of the European Union. If we want a proper use of the European budget, we must first avoid errors in the management of funds, and the Court is very clear in that regard: the best way to reduce the risk of error is to simplify the rules. What is not at odds with effective internal controls, where the use of new technologies can make them more comprehensive and effective. Secondly, we must prevent fraud and corruption at all costs. In this we should also take advantage of new technologies, such as Arachne, which is capable of identifying risks of fraud, conflict of interest or other irregularities in European funds. For this reason, all Member States should use it, and not just in structural funds: also in the future Recovery and Resilience Mechanism. Simplification and new technologies will undoubtedly help to speed up the absorption of funds, which are of great concern lately, especially those who forget the N+3 rule. Let's not be exhausted. Let us focus on improving the performance and results of the European budget.

name: Virginie JORON
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the annual report of the European Court of Auditors is an excellent moment in this parliamentary year 4.0. The Court is doing serious and incisive work that you should read. Why did the Anti-Fraud Office investigate only 34 of the 107 reports provided by the Commission? Why is only 55% of cohesion spending available in the Arachne Fraud Detection Tool? In responding to this report and before this Parliament, the Commission even stated that it had no statistics on the impact of corruption in 2019. Work not carried out, activities or beneficiaries ineligible and irregularities in public procurement: in the end, auditors come to the conclusion that in 2019, the level of error is widespread. The auditors therefore expressed an unfavourable opinion on EU spending.  As for the European Structural and Investment Funds, EUR 300 billion of commitments had not yet been liquidated by the end of 2019, two years of a backlog of budgets. France had absorbed only 45% of the financing to which it is entitled. And you want Brussels to manage 750 billion euros of post-COVID stimulus? In its reports, the Court is also surprised that the recognition rate of Afghan asylum seekers varies between 6 and 98 per cent, depending on the state. The French know which side Emmanuel Macron's France is on. In a recent report cited by Le Figaro, the UN estimates that nearly 16 million Afghans are in need of humanitarian assistance, raising fears of a large wave of immigration for the French authorities. It has long since been a long time since Paris has controlled anything in all areas of security, economic or health, except to control and punish those who forget the curfew at 6 p.m. Colleagues, let us take back control of our destiny, this money is ours.

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: – Madam President, I’m very pleased that the European Court of Auditors (ECA) finally started conducting a performance assessment of annual EU spending. This allows us to evaluate the real impact of EU investments. Unfortunately, Member States are still providing us with very unreliable data. They are way too optimistic on the true value for money spent on local projects. This is our main challenge and it is why I believe that the ECA should conduct more of its own audits. The high level of error in cohesion policy is especially concerning. There are very different results depending on the data used. It seems that 10% of bank agencies for cohesion funds are showing errors, as we are seeing in Slovakia with a large corruption scandal. Even more problematic are the huge conglomerates in central Europe, like the Agrofert Group, which belongs to the Czech Prime Minister, which shows deficiencies in managing EU subsidies, with a 67% error rate in the latest audit report. So I’m asking what can the ECA and the Commission do to reduce this high error rate and guarantee EU money is being spent responsibly?

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, on these crisis days, it is very important that the results of the money we put from the European Union into the national budget are generated very efficiently and bring added value.  It is absolutely inconceivable that they should go to some fraudulent groups, mafias or oligarchs who are waiting for this money and who are very good at getting this money out of the European budget. In fact, there needs to be an added value of European cooperation and solidarity. We have been trying to draw the attention of the European Commission and the Member States to this for a long time. It is precisely the discharge process that serves to prove it. We must try to find effective solutions that will help the citizens of the European Union and not just them. I think it is good that we have done this report, that it turns out that a lot of money is not being drawn very well. The absorption of Member States' funds is slow. By the end of 2019, only 40%, or EUR 184 billion, had been paid out, and some Member States had drawn less than a third. That is why we will want to reform some of the institutions and we will ask the European Commission for a plan called Better Europe that will improve the functioning of the European Union.

name: Lara WOLTERS
text: – Mr President, in 2019, the European Court of Auditors found too many errors in the European budget. This was about 2019, a year without a pandemic, without economic recessions and without the necessary European aid package. With the release of a huge amount to help European economies, tight controls on european money spending are particularly important. It is important that this aid money should go to people who have been hit hardest, that Europe should be committed to a social and green recovery. I therefore call on the European Commission to make use of the rule of law mechanism from now on, without giving in to the delaying tactics and tricks of oligarchs and autocrats, because only then will economic recovery, the protection of fundamental rights and the protection of taxpayers' money go hand in hand.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the work of the rapporteur, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the At the very beginning, I would like to express my sincere thanks to both the President, Klaus Heiner Lehne, and Tony Murphy and Jan Gregor for this year's annual report and, of course, the work of the entire team of the European Court of Auditors. name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, I am glad, as the other colleagues have said, that, behold, the Court of Auditors' report this time also focuses on the cost-benefit ratio. name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Mr President, Members of Parliament. Thank you for this good, committed discussion. A few comments, if i may, first of all, if you really look at the evolution of error rates over the last ten years, then there is definitely a significant decline. When I left the position of Regional Commissioner in 2014, the error rate was around 5 to 6% at the time, and I did not think that it was possible to go much lower than that. In the meantime, however, this is the case. Number one. Number two: But we should also see the price in the truest sense of the word. In other words, 2 000 people are working all year round to relieve the European Union in the Member States at European level. In other words, we must strike the right balance between the use of resources and the effect. Overall, I believe that we are on the right track. I remember when I started ten years ago, it was still N+2, and we did it anyway. And we even had a higher absorption rate because there was just the pressure. In other words, my proposal, as always, is to return to N+2, ideally N+1, and then we would definitely have a smaller number of outstanding commitments. Third and final point: staffing levels. I understand all this. We also had the discussion in the course of the MFF. As you know, we have not received any significant allocations in terms of additional staff. However, I must also say that we must all develop a certain amount of creativity here together. Because yes, we almost have a doubling of the normal budget. But this is a temporary matter – at least from today's point of view. So when we look at how we deal with this issue – on the implementation side, but also on the control side – then we must also be aware that this is a temporary, temporary matter and that we cannot build up a staff ingesstep here, which we may not need afterwards. So together we need not only a certain flexibility, but also creativity. Once again, thank you for your commitment to keeping the supervisory functions within the European Union at this high level.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: Mr President of the Court of Auditors. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank you for the contributions and for the interesting discussion. A few comments also from my side on what has been said. Mrs Penkova, Mr Sarvamaa have pointed out the areas in which the real problems lie: competition, research and cohesion. The fact is that in 2019, it is precisely in the high-risk areas that more expenditure has taken place than in previous years. That is why, I would like to say, the development towards this opinion, if you look at it realistically, has been a predictable development, if you look at the situation in these budgetary sectors over the past few years. That is how I ask you to understand it. I can only confirm emphatically what the Commissioner has just said: if we look at developments over the last ten to twenty years, we have come forward not just one, but a whole host of enormous steps forward. The fact that there are fluctuations in the result, sometimes in one direction or the other, is perfectly normal, especially since we are also working with statistical methods here. Nevertheless, if we act according to our own self-image, we must, of course, put the facts on the table and also say what is and what we have established. The consequences must then be drawn by the executive and the legislature, as far as it considers it necessary. That is not our job. On the subject of performance reporting, I would just like to say in principle that performance and compliance are two sides of the same coin. Mrs Hohlmeier was right to point out – and there were others – that there is no point at all if we have perfect compliance, for example, the specific tender for the construction of a bridge or for an airport terminal or anything has gone perfectly, and since there are no legal errors in it, but nobody or hardly anyone uses this airport terminal or bridge afterwards. In other words, the question of meaningfulness must, of course, also be examined. This is what, of course, has to be checked as part of a performance test in terms of performance, performance. I also believe that this is of particular interest to Members, to the executive, but also, of course, to the public, whether or not these funds have been spent sensibly on certain objects and products, in other words whether they have also been effective. I think that is crucial. This is why the Court has significantly stepped up performance work in the past. Incidentally, as far as this performance report, this accompanying report, is concerned, we will be discussing in the Court this week how we will continue to do so. As I said, this was a pilot project and experience must of course be drawn from the pilot project, or there may be adjustments here or there depending on the course of this week's discussion, but I believe that in principle – if I may say my personal opinion here – this was a step in the right direction, and I certainly believe that this was the case. , that this makes sense in principle, even if, of course, we still have to talk about details and implementation in the individual use of funds. Mr Kuhs is, of course, absolutely right: financial control must be effective, this is not an issue. However, I also believe that we, as the European Court of Auditors, feel in good hands here in this House and have always received the appropriate support here. As I said, we will certainly come to you with regard to additional human resources and technical resources in the preparation of the next budgets, although we are well aware, as the Commissioner has also said here, that the change in budgetary structures is about – yes, seasonal is perhaps understated, but it is about temporary expenditure. That is why we will continue to make appropriate proposals to you, which means that doubling the budget will not lead to a doubling of staffing requirements. I believe that this is logical and clear and does not require any further discussion. But, of course, we must also be able to cope sensibly with the increased effort. The issue of the reliability of the information we have has also been raised. So anyone who reads this report, Mr Pieper, will notice that we have made very clear distinctions as to where we can use data materials that have been made available to us by Member States or by the Commission and where we cannot use them. We only take such data material, where we are sure that it has the same quality as if it were we are looking at this very carefully and very sustainably. This has been one of the priorities of our activities in the context of the annual report, particularly in recent years. That is another reason why we have had a greater use of resources for the annual report than we might have originally hoped, because these special checks of the data that have been made available to us have, of course, also created additional effort. Mrs Garcia Muoz, Mrs Hohlmeier, Mr Christoforou, and others have also raised the issue of digitisation. The Court will do everything necessary to be prepared for the digital era, which has already begun and which will certainly be of even greater importance. But I would also like to make this quite clear here: this is not something that the Court can do on its own. Some time ago we had an idea from Ernst and Young about the way they audit private companies: same data base, full access to all data at any time, push of a button, complete overview. We cannot do that. We cannot do this because, for example, in cohesion audits, we are dealing with 170 different institutions, institutions, in which we then have to carry out audits, all of which have different data bases, and that makes it impossible. But my dream would be – and this is probably only possible by amending the Financial Regulation with a long lead-up, perhaps over ten years, because it also creates investment and costs, not only here, but also in particular in the Member States – to oblige the Member States and the institutions in the Member States that have to deal with the money in the long term through the Financial Regulation. to provide compatible data. That would be really desirable, i think that would perhaps also be an initiative for this parliamentary term, and that would also make a considerable contribution to us and our work and open up completely new opportunities. I am not sure now whether I have raised all the issues, but I am already over the time that was intended for me. Once again, I would like to express my sincere thanks and wish you every success in the further discussions on the discharge reports.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. For 2019, the European Court of Auditors presented for the first time, together with the Report determining the legality and regularity of the accounts, an assessment of the performance of EU spending programmes, going beyond the formal budget review, to examine the performance of EU policies and the achievement of their objectives in an effective, efficient and economical way (the '3 Es'). Unfortunately, for 2019, the Court of Auditors delivered a negative opinion on the use of EU funds: more than half of them, in fact, were considered high-risk with an error rate estimated at 4.9%. The economic challenges we face and the health, social and economic crisis we are experiencing require the utmost attention to be paid to the correctness and good use of all EU spending programmes, starting with the recovery fund that offers an unprecedented opportunity for European states to restart the economy. In my role as Vice-President of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I will work together with the Court of Auditors and the European Commission to ensure that EU funds are implemented promptly and correctly, in order to support the Member States, and thus support citizens and businesses, to get out of the current economic crisis.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is the debate on the single market reinforcement report prepared by Morten Løkkegaard on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection: the report on the future of free movement of services (2020/2020(INI)).

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you for giving me floor. Unfortunately our rapporteur, Mr Morten Løkkegaard, is not able to present his report – he is stuck in traffic. So therefore I will present the report on strengthening the single market: the future of free movement of services, on behalf of Mr Løkkegaard. This report is extremely relevant right now. The European economy is in a terrible crisis due to the coronavirus, which affects all countries. Last year, the European economy contracted by 7.4%, and the unemployment is rising in all Member States. We need to boost the economy and create jobs. One way to do this is to realise the huge potential in the single market for services. The European Parliament Research Service estimated that the potential gain of completing the single market for services could be around EUR 297 billion, or close to 2% of European EU GDP. The aim of the report is to realise this untapped potential – a potential that doesn’t require new laws or new recovery funds to be established. The three main proposals of the report are: firstly, we must make sure that unjustified barriers in Member States are removed and that Member States enforce the existing rules. Secondly, we must provide legal clarity to businesses and consumers by supplying the necessary information. Thirdly, we must provide transparent evaluation of Member States’ performance. For example, the report suggests using scoreboards to rate Member States’ implementation of the existing rules of the single market. Mr Løkkegaard has asked me to thank all the Groups and the shadow rapporteurs who participated in reaching a compromise for this report. Thank you, all of you, for your hard work and your valuable inputs to this proposal. This area has often been highly debated among the political groups; therefore it’s a victory to reach a consensus. The broad support for this report shows that Parliament now has a majority behind several proposals to strengthen the single market on services. This is an important step in the realisation of the potential. We are facing an urgent need to create jobs and growth in Europe, and strengthening the single market for services is one of the ways to do it. With a broad majority in Parliament, it will be up to Member States and the Commission to follow the proposals in the report and to make use of the opportunity that lies at our feet. We hope that all of you will support the report. Now let me add on my behalf, Madam President. I would like to stress that the service sector accounts for around 70% of the European GDP and a similar proportion of its employment. A better-functioning single market for services is therefore a crucial necessity for a more competitive and innovative European economy. The economic fall-out from the coronavirus pandemic has only increased the urgency of unleashing the full potential of the service sector. We need greater clarity and transparency for businesses and consumers alike. We must remove unjustified barriers that deprive our citizens of jobs, our consumers of choices and our entrepreneurs of competitiveness. For too long, Member States have hidden behind over-regulation of professions and administrative barriers to prevent one of the four freedoms. I was extremely disappointed with the decision to withdraw the Services Notification Directive after the Member States and the Council blocked it. Commissioner, I call on you to engage to find new solutions, new proposals, on how to ensure all four freedoms are fully implemented. You must have the courage to act. Now it’s time to complete the single market for services: now or never.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to first of all welcome this initiative report and thank the rapporteur, as well as all the other colleagues concerned, for the important work done. The Commission would like to stress that we need a functioning and well-functioning single market in services today more than ever before. That is the message that my colleague, Commissioner Breton, in charge of the internal market, would have wanted to point out today and it is the same message that I want to share with you.  I absolutely agree with the central message of this report on the need to deepen the single market in services to strengthen the economic recovery and growth of the European Union. The COVID-19 crisis has clearly shown us how fragile the functioning of the single market can be.  At the same time, she stressed how much the European economy depends on the single market and that when the single market does not work, everyone pays the price: supply chains are interrupted, small and large enterprises cannot source, deliver or sell related goods and services.  I draw a strong lesson: the demands of economies that are more dependent on services or manufacturing industries are the same: to be able to rely on the backbone of a fully operational and resilient single market.  It is therefore time to put an end to the old-fashioned dichotomy between the so-called friends of the industry and the friends of the single market. The crisis has affected a whole range of sectors of our single market and also of services. The latter depends heavily on the free movement of workers and service providers.  They were confronted with closed borders or delays in crossing them. To restore and safeguard free movement, the Commission has made considerable efforts to put in place quick and effective solutions in this regard, as shown by the many guidelines and communications presented.  It is clear that a more integrated, more competitive single market has never been more important for recovery and resilience. It is also an indispensable asset in mastering the dual transition to a greener, more digital economy. And, as the report points out, the services sector accounts for almost three-quarters of the EU's GDP and employment. Services are at the fore in our key industrial ecosystems. Services generate nine out of ten new jobs.  In addition, we are witnessing a growing service of products, and as the crisis has highlighted the essential nature of services for our industry and our economy, I assure you that services will be at the heart of our work on ecosystems. But there is equally convincing evidence that the services market remains fragmented and characterized by weak intra-EU trade and investment.  From this perspective, the initiative report rightly highlights the remaining barriers to services that deprive citizens of jobs, consumers of choice and entrepreneurs of opportunities. It is our common responsibility to combat unjustified restrictions on the way to a genuine single market for services.  Some key themes of the report, but first of all, as you have seen, we have decided to withdraw the proposals on notifications under the Services Directive and the electronic card in the Commission's work programme for 2021. Don't see it as a sign of abandoning our ambitions. On the contrary, while we regret that it has not been possible to continue these initiatives with you, we will mobilize all our resources to draw a new route. First, a few words about implementation and application. Very often, barriers to services are linked to insufficient or incorrect implementation of existing single market rules. You are right to put pressure on both the Commission and the Member States. The improvement of implementation can only be done in close collaboration between the European Union and the national or even local level.  Our long-term action plan on compliance with single market rules reflects this shared responsibility. In addition, the Working Group on the Application of Single Market Rules with Member States plays a key role in addressing obstacles through better implementation and enforcement of the rules. Second, I want to emphasize the importance of prevention. It is often much easier and more effective to prevent barriers to the single market in services than to try to prevent them delete later. The importance of having effective notification procedures and ex ante testing of the single market is undeniable when it comes to avoiding unjustified or disproportionate restrictions in the service sector.  Here we are also working on several fronts. On the one hand on the rigorous application of the Directive on Proportionality Control by Member States, on the other hand, we will mobilise all our resources to improve the application of the notification procedure established under the Services Directive. Thirdly, again, I would like to stress the importance of digitisation. This is a necessary prerequisite for the functioning of the single market for services. The recently adopted digital services and digital market legislation, which is currently being considered by co-legislators, will modernise the EU regulatory framework and will be of paramount importance to the single market services sector. I am also pleased that the initiative report focuses on the role of the single digital portal launched last December. It will gather information, provide much-needed administrative simplification for businesses and eventually set up a one-stop shop. The one-stop shop and other problem-solving and assistance services will be fully integrated into the portal. The success of the portal will now depend largely on the political and operational support of the Member States to put things into practice and we are counting on Parliament to continue to advocate for this. Finally, it is encouraging that the initiative report highlights the role of greater integration of service markets in achieving social goals and sustainability. It goes without saying that services can and must contribute to increasing the sustainability and resilience of our industrial ecosystems while respecting the principles of the circular economy and the objectives of our Green Pact. It is also clear that the objectives of the single market and social and environmental policy can and must go hand in hand for truly sustainable development. In conclusion, much remains to be done and we must work together to strengthen the single market for services. Your initiative report is a useful contribution to this work. In the spring, the Commission will present a review of the industrial strategy in March 2020, to ensure that we take into account the lessons learned from the COVID-19 crisis and the acceleration of transformation processes.  The single market will be central to this. We will take stock of the progress made under the long-term action plan for enforcement. We will also present concrete ideas on how to deal with the crises in our single market and to remove persistent obstacles. This will form the basis of our fruitful and ongoing work to ensure a genuine single market for services.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, it's too bad that the rapporteur couldn't be here. I know traffic jams can be difficult and bad, but this text is worse. This text is an attack on workers' rights. The free movement of services in the European Union all too often facilitates social degradation and dumping. For example, a company from one country can provide services in another country, in the construction or transport sector, without guaranteeing workers the same rights. It also makes it difficult for municipalities to stop a McDonald's that is too close to a school or to regulate Airbnb to keep neighborhoods livable. We had drawn up an opinion from the Committee on Employment, and that was clear: the free movement of services must not harm social rights. In this report, our opinion is completely discarded. You can't do that. It is a call for fewer controls on social dumping and less freedom of regulation for municipalities. Every vote for this text is actually a vote against social rights and against workers' rights. That is why I hope that a majority will vote against this text later.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Dear Vice-President, the freedom to provide services is of utmost importance to the European economy. Indeed, services generate as much as 73 per cent of Europe's GDP and create as many as nine out of ten new jobs. On the other hand, only 6.5% of Europe's GDP is generated from cross-border provision of services. This means that the huge economic potential lies precisely in strengthening the cross-border provision of services, which is the topic of this report.  Internal markets and its four freedoms are the cornerstone of the functioning of the European Union. Unfortunately, freedom of movement of services is the least developed among freedoms of movement in the internal market. This is not only due to the fact that the horizontal legislative framework for services was created only in 2006 with the adoption of the Services Directive, but is that in as many as 20 countries the implementation of this directive was delayed and we know what all the political debates were like on this occasion both at local and national and European level. Scientific studies show that the hidden potential of the single market for services accounts for as much as €297 billion. This is huge money with which we can finance healthcare, support SMEs or invest in protecting the external borders of the European Union and strengthen European competitiveness in times of crisis. That is why we want to send a clear message today that the timely and correct implementation of existing legislation is a guarantor of the completion of the single market. In particular, we must work to remove unjustified national barriers holding back business in the single market. And this report sends a clear message: protectionism in the European Union has no place today. In addition, I would like to stress, of course, that this report strikes a quality balance between this freedom to provide services on the one hand and the protection of social rights on the other. I therefore call for sustained political engagement and comprehensive support at European, national and local level so that the single market for services to live up to its full potential.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I agree with you that the internal market is at the heart of the European Union and of European policy. At the moment, the British are learning exactly how painful it is to no longer be part of this single market. I also find it very, very regrettable that they are no longer.  Yes, the freedom to provide services is one of the most important parts of this internal market. However, it can only go hand in hand with a well-thought-out free movement of people in the European Union. That belongs together, and that is something that we also want to take forward and that we must continue to do. Yes, that's a good thing. In the resolution, the European Parliament has once again sent out very clear signals in favour of this freedom to provide services. The European Parliament is clearly committed to the mutual recognition of professional qualifications – a recognition based on quality, on clear criteria, which have also been designed. The European Parliament is also clearly committed to the fundamental principle of the Services Directive, namely the country of destination principle. The law of the state in which work is carried out must be respected. We do not want social dumping, we do not want the social systems of the Member States to be at common side, but cooperation and an improvement in the rights of citizens, be it social rights, consumer protection, environmental protection, climate protection and all these issues that are so close to our hearts. Yes, we are also clearly committed to the protection of services in the general economic interest, also known in Germany as services of general interest. This is also a very important question: whether it is health, local transport or other issues, these are things that are regulated in the Member States, and that is a good thing. Finally, yes, it is very important that European law is implemented and implemented well.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you very much, mr L'kkegaard, for a truly excellent report. Ladies and gentlemen, if around 70% of EU economic services are services, but services are only around 20% of intra-European trade, then we have far too much wasted potential, because too many Member States still create unjustified barriers to protectionism. However, we need to raise this potential, also on our way out of the economic crisis. More competition means more opportunities, more markets for businesses, more choice at more competitive prices for consumers. This is what we need, above all, for the digital economy. Digital business models, digital services, need to be much easier to scale across the EU. In particular, the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act must also break down barriers. And rules for artificial intelligence and other new disruptive services, technologies must be made at European level. I want us to put the Union at the forefront of innovation. And that is not possible with national solo action. This requires a common European market: the Digital Single Market. The foundation stone for this is a really real market for services. And this report is an excellent start to this.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Gabriel, I do not believe that we are doing a service to the Internal Market of the Union if we are just talking about successes. , I am concerned that in December, a few weeks ago, infringement proceedings were initiated against Italy on the application of the Services Directive. It is clear, in that case, it is also a negligence of the Italian Government, which did not defend a regulation, the one introduced in 2018, and which deserved to continue in a dialogue with the European Commission, which had been opened, but in my opinion that is not a positive example: to start a procedure today, at this stage, with the Italian tourism companies affected , like all European companies, is not a positive sign.  I hope, of course, that the Italian Government will do this, in a context in which, for example, in Italy we have a strong conflict with the judiciary in my region, which writes to the mayors not to apply an Italian law. Are we facing a failure or a success of the Union's internal market and the system of rules that we have set ourselves? Because I, unfortunately, see uncertainty and fear about the application of the Services Directive in Italy – often small businesses, even family businesses – who do not know whether they can invest in their future. And the tourism sector, as Commissioner Breton also said, is one of those most affected by the current crisis.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done The Corona crisis has shown, as if through a burning glass, how important good universal services of general interest are. More than ever, people in the European Union need smart basic health care. But it's not just in Corona times that this is important. Public transport, waste collection or a functioning water supply are the basic framework of our society. Studies have shown that people in regions with weak infrastructure feel abandoned and are more likely to vote far right. Nevertheless, here in the European Parliament and in the Commission, there are forces that still want to liberalise even more, even more, who believe that high standards and public services of general interest are obstacles to a genuine internal market for services. However, ladies and gentlemen, the European internal market is a success story precisely because we have high standards for workers, for the environment and for consumers, because we have enabled local authorities to organise genuine and strong services of general interest. And the EU must not undermine all this, otherwise resentment against Europe will rightly rise. Fortunately, we Greens, together with the Social Democrats, have prevailed on many points in the negotiations on this report. But I want to make one thing very clear today: please do not put the axe on the basic framework of our society in the future either. Let us develop the internal market further, yes, but please with high standards, with effective services of general interest and with strong municipalities!

name: Adam BIELAN
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Union's efforts to deepen the free movement of services, which will increase Europe's sovereignty and competitiveness, especially now, after the experience of the coronavirus epidemic, should be an absolute priority for us. As the initiator of the subject of the report, which is the subject of today's debate, in the absence of important initiatives in this area contained in the European Commission's priorities presented at the beginning of this mandate, I would like to congratulate Mr Løkkegaard on a very good report.  The report takes into account a number of extremely important problems that we have to face in the European market. Not only has the importance of the services sector for the European economy been recognized, but also the losses suffered by the Community due to existing barriers and limited implementation by Member States. The development of disruptive technologies in Europe is being significantly hampered precisely because of the fragmentation of the EU services market.  I am therefore pleased that the final text stresses the need for urgent action to create an efficient market for services, which should be one of the priorities in the fight against the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic. They are also crucial for an effective industrial policy and for increasing the competitiveness of businesses. I hope that the solutions called for will contribute to removing unjustified barriers to the free movement of services. We must constantly strive to support small and medium-sized enterprises and their cross-border activities. I hope that the report will show the European Commission the direction to take until the end of its term of office.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: for The Left group. Madam President! It is very important for EU Member States to protect the good of the community and, for example, to prevent Airbnb from causing house prices in European cities to explode. Apparently not if it's up to denmark's Liberal Party. In the European Parliament, Liberal Party Group Chairman Morten Løkkegaard proposes in a report that Member States should be limited in their ability to regulate the internal market in services. It will undoubtedly be a liberalist dream. But it will not only be a disaster for ordinary people looking for affordable housing and finding it impossible to find a rental property for the police officer or nurse who is affordable. That is why, of course, the Unity List is voting against the Liberal party's proposal, and so does the Group of the European Left.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As has already been said, the Corona crisis has shown, particularly in the border regions of Europe from which I come, how important the European internal market is for people to be able to meet and also to be able to carry out work in their professional activities on the other side of the border. The Services Directive, ladies and gentlemen, has been in place since 2006. It was jointly adopted by the Council and Parliament. The fact that the Member States are now constantly trying to reverse certain provisions of the Services Directive is rightly offshooting the European Union among the citizens in the border area. After all, three quarters of the European Union's economic output is made up of services. And, ladies and gentlemen, if we want to get out of the crisis, we need this European internal market, and the service providers will be able to make a very important contribution to this. We should make use of this contribution, ladies and gentlemen. They can be cultural workers, they can be architects, they are many nurses or dentists. There are a wide range of activities that are now expected to play an important role in the internal market and in Europe for more growth. And this growth should be possible – not against the Member States, but with the Member States. With this in mind, I hope that the report will receive a great deal of support.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Thank you also for a good debate on this report on the free movement of services. Fundamentally, we Socialists believe that the internal market is the engine of European cooperation and, of course, for it to work, there must also be a form of free movement, including services. But it only works if we ensure that freedom of movement goes hand in hand with fairness. In the report we are discussing today – the Løkkegård report – we Social Democrats have ensured a much better balance in the relationship between freedom of movement and fairness. And that is why we support the report. Let me highlight a few of the things that we think are very good in the report: firstly, with the report, we are giving a very clear signal to the Commission that we do not want an e-service card. We therefore support the decision to withdraw it. We don't want it. We do not believe that this will create a fair internal market. Secondly, I also think it is really important that we ensure fairness for workers, and that is why it is good that we are committed to the european labour authority being fully operable, and we are putting pressure on that. The third, which I also think is important, is that we should focus on the development of a European social security number so that we can strengthen legal certainty for our workers and combat social fraud more effectively. All this is the prerequisite for us to have a fair internal market in services. We must ensure that freedom of movement goes hand in hand with fairness around it. And then, of course, it is also hugely important that we protect all the special services that are in the public sector – the public tasks of, for example, health and education, etc. It should not be the subject of ordinary classical freedom of movement. We believe that we have ensured this in this report. That is also why we support it.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report. I think it indicates quite clearly that there are still huge barriers to the financial services in the Single Market. There is no doubt: if we are to be serious about ensuring that Europe works for the citizens, the area of financial services is a key area that has to be addressed. We have to remove the barriers. Some of them are historic, but more are left there intentionally because of nationalistic financial services’ views of Member States. So, if we are to work for citizens, I highlight a particular issue that is very relevant in the everyday lives of people in Ireland. The average mortgage rate in Ireland is 2.9%. The EU average is 1.3%. That is a key area where financial services is not functioning on behalf of the citizens of Ireland. The Irish banking system is gouging profits from mortgage holders in Ireland. So clearly, we need to ensure there’s no barriers, remove the obstacles, create competition and ensure that citizens benefit – and in this context, Irish mortgage holders and small businesses – to ensure that they have fair interest rates.

name: Virginie JORON
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you are proposing in this report the strengthening of the single market, as a mantra, when it is precisely the only policy that has been implemented by the European Union since Maastricht and which has led to such disaffection of the citizens of the continent towards our institution. However, it is the application of such laissez-faire that has weakened our European economic and industrial structures and left us very destitute at the time when the health crisis appeared.  You are calling for the creation of an internal market bulletin board to monitor the performance of Member States, as well as indicators of restrictiveness, so that the Commission can set annual targets for reducing obstacles and opening up the market that are binding and subject to scrutiny, with the possibility of infringement procedures. Great is my fear that in this way French social security will seem far too restrictive and thus be dismantled to satisfy your liberal aims. Your unlimited openness would thus be articulated by a task force on compliance with the rules of the single market. It is to be feared that this police of liberalism will further distance the peoples of Europe from their real freedom and their ability to control their economy.  But what keeps my mind is your repeated call for the ever-increasing opening of Europe's borders. Thus, your project would be as authoritarian in respecting the dogmas of free trade, as it was lax and disrespectful of peoples' expectations of unwanted but nevertheless imposed immigration.  This text therefore embodies this European policy which is causing so much harm to Europe by taking away from its beautiful idea the European citizens aghast at its diversion in the service of the global market.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Madam President. Ladies and gentlemen, it is the corona crisis that shows us the importance of the common European market. Just today, many companies that have lost the opportunity to do business in their home country can find customers in other countries in the common market. This is particularly the case in the services sector, which accounts for up to 70% of European GDP and whose share of employment is similar.  We have been talking about the completion of the common market for a long time. I myself, also as President of SME Europe, have contributed a number of proposals. Today, in particular, I would like to highlight three areas.  Firstly, there are still serious obstacles in the common market which make it impossible for small businesses, in particular, to benefit from it. For example, 36 percent of small businesses cite the absence of translations of rules and legislation into national languages as an obstacle.  Secondly, we have made progress in the area of recognition of qualifications, but we still need to improve the comparability of levels of professional qualifications, particularly because of the mutual recognition of education and practice in services.  Thirdly, the process of evaluating the European Semester should also be used to strengthen the common market. The removal of barriers to services should therefore become part of the regular country-specific recommendations.  The report presented is useful, it lists many obstacles, and I believe that this report can also contribute to more work in promoting entrepreneurship and completing the common market, especially in the area of services.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Madam President, we have been insisting for years that there is a need for a flawless internal market for services by unlocking the benefits for businesses and consumers. Today, this goal has become an emergency. In the face of the crisis, the completion of a Europe of services goes hand in hand with continental recovery. We voted on measures that were previously unthinkable to respond to the crisis. So, ladies and gentlemen, is it unthinkable to achieve a real European market for services today? I do not think so because, yes, today there is an urgent need to act also for the ecological transition and for the digital transition.  The report by Mr Lukkegaard makes this very clear. It is time to deepen our single market for services, it is time to put an end to unjustified barriers. To that end, we must make full use of the tools at our disposal, accelerated infringement procedures , and I turn here to the Commission - performance tools, such as the internal market bulletin board or the SOLVIT service.  For today, ladies and gentlemen, we have no time for excuses: it is time to act.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President. Services account for three quarters of the Union's GDP. Between 2000 and 2017, labour productivity in services grew at half the rate of the United States in the European Union. At the same time, there are large differences in productivity growth between Member States. Over the same period, Italian labour productivity fell by four percent, while Estonian productivity increased by 61 percent. If we increase productivity in services to the level of the three most successful States of the Union, gross domestic product could grow by around 5 percent. What are the tasks of this for the Commission and the Member States? The Commission and the Member States should therefore come up with analyses of best practices and incentives to reform. The closest to evaluating recovery plans. We should also push for further removal of barriers in the services market. For example, by reducing the number of regulated professions of which there are about 6 000 in the Union. Today's restrictions do not protect consumers from poor quality services from other Member States, they only protect producers from competition, to the detriment of consumers and the whole of the Union, as well as its members. What the selected producers earn from safeguard measures is smaller than what consumers lose. Further liberalisation is therefore essential and desirable for the whole of the European Union.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is constantly making a mistake and locking itself into outdated ideological orientations, and this report, which we are referring to today, illustrates this in a cartoonish way.
