Yet the pandemic had demonstrated the importance of controlling our borders, our supply chains, our short circuits and regaining sovereignty in strategic areas. And what does the report do? Quite the opposite. He calls for easier implementation of foreign companies, says that reopening borders is the priority and fanatically rejects any idea of localism. On the other hand, the pandemic revealed that liberalism and globalism had allowed large companies to relocate their activities to countries with the most detestable social conditions. And what does the report do? Instead of remedying it, he throws himself into an even more total freedom of movement. Finally, the pandemic proved that it was essential to keep the right of the state to intervene intact in the economy. And what does the report do here, too? He described this right as illegitimate and called for the abandonment of safeguards of public interest, which he described as unjustified. So, ladies and gentlemen, the show would not be complete without one last horror: the inclusion of each state in a table of encrypted performance on freedom of movement, with annual targets for removing obstacles under the supervision and control of the European Commission. As if the states were small employees evaluated by their bosses on their performance.  Well, we reject this organization. We reject this catastrophic organization of the world and the damage it causes. We must leave these dogmatic fantasies based on the abstract ideology of pure freedom. There is an urgent need to build a national, humane, resilient society that protects our economies and the social conditions of our workers.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab One of the fundamental values of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union is the freedom to provide and flow services in the common market. This freedom, together with the freedom of establishment, guarantees mobility and facilitates the functioning of entrepreneurs within the European Union. Strengthening the services market will bring tangible benefits to all Member States and the gradual elimination of barriers in this area must become a priority for the coming years.  We must effectively combat restrictions and behaviour that discriminate against the service provider on the basis of origin or place of business. Such wicked conduct not only affects the service provider, but primarily affects recipients of services. Additional certification requirements, frequent and oversized inspections are just a few examples of mistreatment of Polish companies providing services in the common market. The restriction on the freedom to provide services does not lead to a level playing field in the European Union, but, on the contrary, to the perpetuation of inequalities. We should change that.

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as archdefender of the internal market, we have been talking about improving the internal market for 25 years, because that is the most important thing that the European Union has achieved. I agree with that. A free market, it must be there, because it provides extra prosperity, but can never be a reason for social abuse. And yet we see it taking place all the time. We also see that the internal market is not working or not working enough. I call on the Member States, in the Council, to give the European Commission more opportunities to actually improve this internal market and to ensure that abuses do not take place.  We have had Brexit since 1 January. We know that the Uk economy is mainly made up of services. The United Kingdom is no longer a member of the single market and should therefore not be given the same opportunities as the countries that are members and contribute to everything that the European Union represents. I hope that the Memorandum of Understanding, which will soon be concluded, will continue to be a clear difference between those countries that are members of the European Union and those that are third countries or are not members of the European Union. I call on the Commission, and I call on everyone, to ensure that Europe first is always an important starting point of that internal market and that the European Commission will ultimately have real powers to intervene, to improve that internal market, and to prevent social abuses.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I ask you, I have been listening to what you are saying for a long time, and I wonder how you can look in the mirror. Because you come here to the lecch and say that more of the single market is needed. And then you go back to your cabinets and you pass a mobility package that restricts the single market just because the countries of old Europe were doing better, the companies from the countries of old Europe were doing better than those from the new Europe. You come here and say that you have to treat workers in the single market in solidarity, and then you go back to the cabinets and you pass the Posted Workers Directive, limiting these opportunities for workers, because workers from the old countries are doing better than workers from the new countries. Tomorrow there will be a debate here where you will say: Do not allow Putin to arrest Nawal! And then you will go back to your offices and sign Nord Stream II. It is high time for the integrity of your words with your actions.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The effectiveness of the action against the coronavirus is reflected in the ability of the EU and the Member States to deliver. Unfortunately, as a result of the epidemic, partly due to the belated EU response, our internal market has unfortunately almost collapsed after, among other things, the flow of health services and products has stopped. In addition, there are many examples of an increase in the use of unfair commercial practices.  I believe that the inadequate implementation of the Services Directive has had harmful consequences for both consumers and service providers in the European Union, and that unjustified administrative obstacles are particularly suffered by small and medium-sized enterprises. The single market can only be achieved through a joint effort, not only through new targeted legislation, but also through more effective implementation, information sharing and evaluation. I call on the Commission to take the necessary steps as soon as possible to protect the internal market.

name: Salvatore DE MEO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and, above all, for having been able to find the right compromise between the various political groups. The services sector is important for the single market: 9 out of 10 jobs in the European Union are created thanks to this sector and better harmonisation can mean up to 2 % more GDP. I am in favour of an increase in services, particularly cross-border services, which will create new job opportunities but, at the same time, show that this initiative does not go in the right direction for the bathing sector. Unfortunately, some aspects of the Bolkestein Directive have created a legislative framework unfavourable to the bathing sector, which is strategic for the tourism sector. In European countries such as Italy, where the economy of bathing tourism is an important component of the economy, it is necessary to find more appropriate and effective solutions than is currently reported in the Services Directive, for which it would be necessary to clarify whether it is also applicable to state concessions. That is why I am abstaining from voting on this initiative.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again I welcome the initiative report on services. It underlines the major importance of the single market in services and that much more needs to be done to make it more efficient. We all know that it is not easy to advance integration in the sensitive area of services. These difficulties are evident in our debates on services in this House.  But we must improve the single market and work towards a greener, more digital and resilient single market that delivers results for all. This is all the more important in the current context, as we try to draw a path out of the crisis.  I therefore count on the support of the European Parliament and I look forward to continuing our cooperation to continue working, to remove obstacles and to work towards a fully operational single market in services.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday 20 January 2021. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: Writing. Mr President, honourable Members appreciate that the provision and use of services throughout Europe has become a daily occurrence for businesses and consumers in the Member States. Improving the Services Directive, which has already been ratified, can therefore only be in the interests of all parties involved. However, the EU must accept that it cannot flout existing law in the member states and, incidentally, derogatoryly treat these laws as "unjustified barriers" to access to the single market. The demand for a European social security number is also nothing more than the desire for a single European social system, which is tantamount to further disempowering the Member States and must be rejected outright. Equally strongly, the instrumentalization of the internal market in order to implement an excessive and economic-destroying environmental idea in the form of the Green Deal must be rejected.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – One of the best ways to ensure the prosperity and wellbeing of European citizens for generations to come is by completing the Single Market. The EU Single Market is one of our greatest strengths: it stimulates competition and trade, improves efficiency, raises quality and helps cut prices. It accounts for 450 million consumers and 22.5 million small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). However, we still have to take some steps before the true completion of the Single Market. An area in which the Single Market can be strengthened is in the free movement of services. Services account for 70% of all economic activity in the EU and create 90% of new employment. Cross-border trade in services, on the other hand, generates only 6.5% of the EU’s GDP. This shows a clear need to further stimulate the free movement of services by effectively and coherently implementing existing legislation, the use of public procurement where needed to reduce the costs of cross-border procurement for SMEs, micro-enterprises and self-employed, and the use of the European Semester to remove administrative and regulatory barriers when presenting country-specific recommendations. Completing and strengthening the Single Market is also crucial to a resilient economic recovery from the COVID-19 crisis.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is the report by Dace Melbārde on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education on the effective policy heritage of the European Year of Cultural Heritage (2019/2194(INI)).

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, honourable colleagues, Honourable Commissioner, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-3, for the work done. Cultural heritage is a source of our common wealth, which brings evidence of European history, maintains a living memory of civilisation, inspires us to create new cultural values in the present and offers us lessons to build our common future. Cultural heritage forms the core of the path of each individual and community. It represents our different traditions, languages, lifestyles, but at the same time helps us to become aware of the common that unites us all. Europe's unique, diverse cultural space is made up of countless cultural treasures, whether tangible and intangible, movable and immovable, printed, audiovisual and digital. In order to better understand this range of rich values, 2018 was announced as the European Year of Cultural Heritage. During this period, more than 23 000 events took place in Europe, involving 12.8 million people in all Member States. The European Year of Cultural Heritage was an excellent achievement and, to a large extent, we must thank the Member States and civil society organisations that have played an important role in shaping it. The European Parliament's report, which I have created, must be seen as a roadmap for what needs to be done in the future, so that the successes and developments of the Year of Cultural Heritage are a lasting follow-up to the future. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the shadow rapporteurs here and all the administrative staff, as well as the civil society activists, who have done a great deal of work to help prepare this report. Firstly, it was important for us in the report to highlight the versatility of the value of cultural heritage. Undoubtedly, cultural heritage is a value in itself, not just an suffix for other industries and industries. The cultural heritage sector in Europe is an important driver of growth and employment, employing around 300 000 people, while 7.8 million jobs in Europe are indirectly linked to it. The industry's estimated employment growth rate is very high, ahead of many other sectors. Cultural tourism is a particular driver of growth in the European Union, as four out of ten tourists choose their destination depending on its cultural offering. Europeans are unanimous in assessing cultural heritage. According to the Eurobaromentra survey, 84% of respondents in the Member States believe that cultural heritage is important to them personally and to the local community they create, while eight out of ten respondents consider cultural heritage to be important for the whole of the European Union. The report also highlights aspects of cultural heritage education. Cultural heritage enriches the educational process and content with values and new educational opportunities. Education, on the other hand, is the most important means of maintaining cultural heritage and maintaining the inheritance chain. Aware of this synergy, the availability of Europe's cultural heritage and the active participation of the public in its knowledge and preservation should be extended, including through European Union programmes and initiatives such as the European Capital of Culture, Creative Europe, Erasmus+, the European Heritage Label and others. In the context of education, one of the challenges is the lack of qualified cultural heritage specialists – restorers and skilled craftsmen. It is therefore important to ensure stable funding for the preparation of professionals in the fields of cultural heritage. It is also necessary to strengthen intergenerational dialogue and the relationship between masters and apprentices for the inheritance of skills. The report also stresses the need to develop a comprehensive European Union framework with adequate funding to better identify and preserve the digital heritage, given its growing importance, especially during a pandemic. Indeed, it is not possible to overestimate the rapid reaction of cultural and creative industries and the expression of solidarity during the Covid-19 crisis, ensuring that the public has wide-ranging online access to culture. Among other things, we experienced the creation of many new innovative cultural values in the digital environment, which today is already an asset— a valuable testimony of this age. However, one cannot talk about the negative impact of Covid-19 on the cultural and creative sector : museums, galleries and other cultural heritage sites, including tourist attractions, closing their doors to visitors, drastically reduced their sources of revenue, severely undersaly understizing the management of cultural monuments and the well-being of those employed in the cultural sector. To this point, it is the right time to work on sustainable funding models for preserving cultural heritage in order to reduce its dependence on commercial activities. The report reiterates Parliament's call for a better integrated and coordinated approach to the preservation of Europe's cultural heritage by the Commission and for improved internal cooperation with different policies and administrations. The report also calls for the development and appropriate funding of a permanent platform for cooperation and coordination in the field of cultural heritage policy at European Union level, centred on organised civil society. To conclude, I am convinced that the european Parliament's the report will serve as a new impetus for the assessment, preservation and application of the value of cultural heritage in the European Union and its Member States. This will also provide new initiatives, such as the experience and expertise accumulated in the field of cultural heritage and its preservation, to contribute to strengthening a European way of life, to the priorities of Digital europe and the Green Course, and to stimulating a sustainable economy. I hope that the report will strengthen our conviction that every European has the right to live in a quality cultural environment and, at the same time, a duty to take care of its sustainability.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to begin by expressing my sincere gratitude for the efforts you have focused on the European Year of Cultural Heritage, as well as for your valuable work on this report. A warm thank you is extended to the rapporteur Mrs Melb-rde. We all know very well that the European Year of Cultural Heritage was a great success, almost 13 million people participated, 23,000 events organized in 37 countries. But this is a common success because it has involved all THE EU institutions, national coordinators and civil society organisations in a truly multi-party approach. This success is also due to the excellent cooperation and support of the European Parliament.  The European Year of Cultural Heritage was not a one-off initiative, we continue to implement a longer-term vision to manage, safeguard and enhance Europe's cultural heritage, because, yes, cultural heritage is the soul of Europe. It is part of our European and national identity. It gives us a sense of common identity and inspires a better future.  Cultural heritage is an economic asset, a unique wealth, and contributes to social cohesion. And this is the case with the European Framework for Cultural Heritage, which, as you know, includes more than 60 activities aimed at boosting the results of the European year. Several activities in the framework are already responding to calls in this report. The challenge and the challenge is to follow up on it. I was also pleased to see that the Cultural Heritage in Action project is mentioned in your report and this project is an example of action included in the framework, which is consistent with the integrated approach to cultural heritage.  Therefore, it is crucial to maintain cooperation, the unique political dialogue carried out during the European year. And that's why in 2019 we have created a group of experts on cultural heritage that serves as a platform for cooperation and policy coordination. I would like to thank once again the honourable members of the group, Mrs Melb-rde and Mrs Ojdrov, who represent the European Parliament in this group. Now, ladies and gentlemen, let me make some comments on some of the key issues raised in this report. As a starting point, I am pleased to see that he attaches great importance to education and skills and rightly so. The report stresses the importance of educating younger generations about their heritage and history, and I could not agree more. In this regard, a very good example of the legacy of the European Year is the joint project with UNESCO on the integration of intangible cultural heritage into school learning programmes.  As the European Commission, we are very committed to this important aspect: safeguarding cultural heritage necessarily means safeguarding the skills of cultural heritage professionals. Indeed, the Commission mobilises funds for actions in this area, and this through the various programmes we have at our disposal, from creative Europe to Erasmus.  Now we will have to think about what new instruments we can mobilise in the European Education Area, in the digital action plan, how we can use micro-qualifications but also centres of professional excellence, simply to broaden learning opportunities. With regard to climate change and its impact on cultural heritage, you know that this is a subject close to our hearts. The Commission brings together experts from EU Member States as part of a working group to identify and exchange best practices and innovative measures to protect the cultural heritage of climate change. Experts are working to have a report published in 2022. The report also mentions economic potential and sustainability. The preservation of cultural heritage is an expensive activity. Member States' public budgets are sometimes subject to severe constraints, including due to the current crisis. That's why we're holding a two-day workshop next week on other sources of cultural heritage funding. In December, we also launched a climate education coalition.  Culture is at the heart of climate change. The fight against climate change requires an innovative and creative exchange between many disciplines, including culture, and this must be one of our top priorities for us to build together a sustainable future for Europe. In addition, as part of the European Capital of Culture initiative, networking activities and synergies with innovation capitals, green capitals will also continue as part of the joint action plan we have adopted with the Committee of the Regions. This deserves more attention.  The Commission also places a high priority on sustainable cultural tourism, which is strictly linked to this issue. The Working Group for Sustainable Cultural Tourism, made up of representatives from Member States, is a good example of the work being done on sustainability. This group created the first-ever definition of sustainable cultural tourism and made more than 50 recommendations.  However, cultural heritage is not limited to material and intangible aspects alone. The year 2020 showed us the importance of accessibility to digital cultural heritage like never before. I am pleased to see that the rapporteur stresses the importance of the Europeana project. It is also expected that the Digital Europe Programme will support the digital transformation of cultural heritage.  And that's how I come to innovation. Digital heritage innovation reminds me that cultural heritage is also a strategic area of the Commission's research and innovation policy. Around 600 million euros are already being spent on cultural heritage in the Horizon 2020 programme. We will have a new cluster with a budget of 900 million euros in the new program.  Today, we need to increase their visibility, but above all to make these instruments accessible to as many people as possible. And it is precisely within the framework of the Horizon Europe programme that we will be working, including for innovative services such as the cloud, i.e. a collaborative area of European cultural heritage, a reference to a possible cloud of European cultural heritage, as requested by the European Parliament during the negotiations of the Horizon Europe programme. In addition, we also need high-quality digital educational content based on European cultural diversity and creativity, which is why the Commission is planning to launch a feasibility study on the creation of a European exchange platform. Europe needs to catch up and create its own common space to share certified online resources and link existing educational platforms.  Finally, cooperation on illicit trafficking, to which the report also devotes its attention, is one of the Commission's priorities in the field of international cultural relations. UNESCO is one of the EU's most important partners in the fight against illicit trafficking. The EU supports several UNESCO training and learning modules for different occupational categories. Ladies and gentlemen, I thank you at this stage for your attention and I look forward to listening to your discussion on this interesting report.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your really constructive, and I would like to say not only formally, but also such a personal, enthusiastic approach to this subject. It has been an honour to be shadow rapporteur and to work with My Colleague Melbarde on this report. Much has already been said about the importance of cultural heritage. Cultural heritage, these are our roots, that is our identity, and that is why we should get to know them, we should nur them and also pass on cultural heritage to future generations. It's our DNA, but it's also an economic asset. We do not have a sea in the Czech Republic, so we say, "Monuments are our seas." This is the source for our tourism. But Italy, for example – we know very well that ancient monuments in Rome, for example, have greater financial benefits than exports of the automotive industry in Italy. And we can continue with examples of other countries. In short, we are supposed to take care of cultural monuments not only for their value, but also for their economic contribution. This is also what our report talks about and highlights, among other things, the need for digitalisation, the need for networking between institutions, monuments, between schools, highlighting the contribution to the young generation, education. And we also stress cooperation with UNESCO. I would like to say that cultural heritage is an inspiration, and that is why we are calling for a new European Year of Cultural Heritage, which can take advantage of the challenge of today. Whether it's digitalization, whether it's new directions in architecture, the so-called green architecture of the New Bauhaus. I thank the European Commission very much for its support and I believe that the new European Year of Cultural Heritage will and will be successful.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I thank the rapporteur, Mrs Melbsrde, for her excellent work and cooperation among the political groups, and also Commissioner Mariya Gabriel for attending our debate. The report highlights that, thanks to the European Year of Cultural Heritage, it has been possible for all actors in the field of heritage at local, regional and national levels, as well as European, and civil society to work together for heritage, and calls for continuity in this way of working. We are also calling for the digitisation of European cultural heritage and the acceleration of the Union's action, in particular in education and vocational training of workers. It should also be noted, however, that this Parliament was the first institution in 1974 to adopt a text on cultural policy and heritage support. Forty-seven years after this report, Parliament is once again a pioneering institution, in part with this position we are adopting today. But we remain far from some of the objectives that were identified then, taking into account the memorandum on Community action in cultural matters promoted by Altiero Spinelli, which gives our building its name. Thus, we still do not have Community competences in the European dimension of education, culture and heritage. And we also need to continue to drive the fight against trafficking in cultural goods. The commissioner said so and I welcome it. We need to launch a European action plan against the trafficking of cultural goods. And on the question of competence, I believe that the Conference on the Future of Europe can be a good opportunity to open that debate.

name: Laurence FARRENG
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Madam rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, of cultural heritage in times of pandemic, there will remain an image, that of the crystal clear waters of Venice. An image that should encourage us to question the evolution of more respectful and sustainable tourism. But cultural heritage in times of pandemic, there will remain mostly closed doors. Our monuments, our museums, our contemporary architectural works, without more visitors. For this, there is an urgent need, for their protection and above all to prepare everywhere for their reopening and to support those who work there. We cannot leave our cultural heritage abandoned. National recovery plans and REACT-EU must provide funding as soon as possible, regional funds can and must also be mobilised. The instruments and budgets are there, all that is missing is the political will of the executives: the Commission, the States and the regions. So let us take advantage of the dynamics and success of the European Year of Cultural Heritage, which I think are not very much exploited, by building a genuine European heritage strategy, by valuing it, by making it visible, by mobilising digital technologies and by showing that it is an ever-changing common good, heritage of yesterday and tomorrow. It is key to our economy, to the economy of our regions but above all it is essential to account for our diversity and our European cultural wealth. To show how close we are.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which Preserving cultural heritage is, of course, a matter of the heart for a group like ours. Because we know that the self-confidence and self-image of our fellow citizens comes from the cultural roots in the first place. Those who have no history, no identity, who do not know who they are and who went before them cannot be citizens, are subjects. "The inner man forms the outer man," Friedrich Schiller put it, and that is the guiding principle for a group that calls itself identity and democracy. In this respect, we naturally support the efforts also supported by this House to protect and develop Europe's cultural heritage. But we also see the danger of being politicised, of protecting not what is cultural and history, but of creating a fake culture that fits in with what you want politically. We have heard it today: climate change should also be involved in protecting cultural heritage. I don't think Beethoven, Baudelaire or Balzac have thought about climate change. If we want to protect culture, it is the one that is there, not the one we construct. Then we want to remember the people who preceded us and not make a choice by overthrowing the monuments. That is why we have tabled amendments to the proposal that is in the room. We ask you to consider these changes so that we can protect Europe's real cultural heritage and not a constructed fake heritage that serves only crude current policies.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, Madam rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, in this context where our heritage sites are almost completely closed, where millions of cultural professionals struggle every day to survive, it was very difficult but also very important to value past successes. Last week, a player from the cultural sector in the southern neighbourhood told me, "Now you understand what life without culture is." He was right. This unprecedented pandemic crisis has reminded us all of the essential value of culture to make society, to accept differences, to build social bonds, to see the world differently, to discover the other than oneself. But once again, our colleagues on the far right are against the project of a heterogeneous, non-hierarchical, shared and inclusive culture. I am particularly proud to have tabled an amendment to include the cultural and linguistic heritage of minorities in Europe in any reflection on European heritage. Cultural heritage is a common good, a universal and multicultural common good. Culture is a bridge between peoples, between societies. It must heal the wounds of the past and create the foundations of the future: this must necessarily involve the recognition and respect of other cultures, including the return of stolen or looted goods during the waves of colonization. Our cultural relationships reflect our societies and identities. I invite my colleagues to work together and courageously to engage in a profound reflection on our history, memories and the colonial past, as well as on our present and especially on the common future that we must build with each other, for as Richard Hoggart so a good said, "No culture is the whole truth".

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – [...] Mr President, in support of rapporteur Melbarde, I will say that cultural heritage is an invaluable resource that the European Union and countries must protect and finance. Every penny invested in conservation and development of cultural heritage sites is an investment that will benefit not only citizens at the moment, but future generations. Special attention must be paid to conservation and it is closely linked to infrastructure as a necessary condition for development and access to cultural heritage.  In Bulgaria we have a huge number of priceless archaeological finds of European and world importance and from personal bad experience I know how many of these sites are discovered and then abandoned. These sites cannot be developed, let alone maintained, due to the lack of adequate infrastructure. When you've uncovered an ancient city in the middle of no where, there can be no flow of tourists. Infrastructure must be a key element in funding. Money must be allocated not only from the cultural budget, but also from the Structural Funds and from regional development funds in order to build conditions for access and exploitation.  I am therefore pleased that the rapporteur and the entire report of College Melbarde are calling for an increase in funding from european regional development funds.

name: Alexis GEORGOULIS
text: on behalf of The Left group. Mr President, in this resolution, the vast majority of CULTURAL MEPs agree that in order to support our heritage we must support people in the sector and face challenges such as climate change, illegal possession and trafficking, which have increased in the midst of a pandemic, but also challenges in the digital transition. In this resolution, too, we join forces for uniform funding and tangible policies, such as the specialisation of professionals and free access to museums. Our cultural heritage is our identity, the one we have received from our ancestors and the one we will deliver to our children, is the ark of human political life in the process and for this reason, the substantial support of our cultural heritage is the responsibility but also a necessity of all of us. This, after all, is what the agreement of the colleagues we have worked on in this resolution shows.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to say at the moment that there is an unbridgeable rift between two worlds. On the one hand, we have kids who enroll in humanities, as I did at the time, art academies, conservatives to cultivate talent or because they're fascinated by history, beauty and art. On the other hand, we have an ultra-liberal policy of cultural heritage, especially the material one, made up of de facto privatisations, with the transfer of our cultural heritage to foundations for fifty years, for ninety years, which makes our history only an unscrupulous business. I hope that the interpretation of Article 167 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union will be to really protect Europe's common cultural heritage, not to sell it to the highest bidder, otherwise all our fine initiatives and fine words are useless! Cultural heritage is our history, what we have been and what we are now. Our job is to preserve it for future generations. Talent and intelligence are like a flower: without water they wither; promoting the development of culture is nourishment.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We in Europe can be proud of our common cultural heritage, which is a reflection of our common identity, a testament to our rich history and the unity of European civilisation through the diversity of our cultural tradition. One thing is clear: it is our duty to protect our cultural heritage. We must maintain it in order to preserve it for future generations. Our cultural heritage is also an economic factor. Around 300 000 people in Europe are employed in this sector, and almost eight million jobs in Europe are indirectly linked to it. Four out of ten people choose their holiday destination according to the cultural offer. This report rightly points out that cultural tourism must strike a balance between economic, social, cultural and environmental requirements. The report calls on the Commission to organise another European Year of Cultural Heritage, and that must be a priority, because having such success once is not enough, it must be designed in the long term, as must the European heritage label, which characterises our cultural heritage and recognises its value to Europe. We must sustainably promote and support this cultural heritage with the help of the European Union. We need strong support for the digitisation of our cultural heritage, and here, as the Commissioner has also said, the Europeana project, which serves as Europe's digital library, as an archive, as a museum and also as an educational platform, is to be highlighted. Our cultural heritage is united in its diversity like nothing else. It is our history and will become part of our future, in accordance with the European motto 'United in Diversity'.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, a third of the sites on the UNESCO Heritage List are in the European Union. The European Year for Cultural Heritage has allowed us to understand the need to allocate additional resources to this area both in the investment area and in the human resource.  I recall here the call to allocate at least 2% of national recovery and resilience plans for the cultural and creative sector. From the beautiful fortress of Alba Iulia to the Colosseum in Rome, from the works of painters in the Netherlands to the writings of famous philosophers in Greece, the preservation of our cultural heritage proves the understanding of the past, but also the ability to project a future for this sector with significant economic potential.  I support the inclusion of the European cultural dimension, including heritage, in the debates on the future of Europe and the active involvement of experts and civil society in heritage policies.  We need a strategic and innovative vision, one that includes all Member States, which relies on education and adapts to technological and digital developments.  The measures are clear and have been mentioned: easier access to European funds, both for small and large projects, the creation of platforms dedicated to learning and the exchange of best practices, support for European networks and initiatives leading to increased cooperation between relevant experts, decision-makers and actors, the creation of a community for cultural and creative industries within the European Institute of Innovation and Technology , the extension of the European heritage mark - and we must say that we have 48 sites, and from my country, Romania, we only have the Sighet Memorial - the popularization of history and heritage from all over Europe through the House of European History - and we have even recently proposed a similar approach including Including Romanian authors and creators - a support, as the Commissioner said, more consistent for European cultural capitals , and I am thinking of the future cultural capital, timişoara, in particular.  By investing in cultural heritage we are actually investing in preserving our past, but especially in designing a common future at European level.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Mr President, cultural heritage is our common source of wealth and is something that we should all actually care for and value more.  2018 was the European Year of Cultural Heritage and the experience gained from the 23,000 events that took place throughout Europe throughout the year, and this experience should be a model for further upgrading in the years to come.  We all know that the cultural sector has now been really badly affected by the pandemic. And we really need to step up our joint efforts to create, together with civil society, permanent platforms for better cooperation and for better cultural heritage policies at European Union level, to highlight digital cultural heritage, to create a single portal for cultural heritage funding, and to find out where there are ways to improve promotion, for better cooperation and ultimately to synergy with other programmes. Last but not least, our key task is to provide more resources and better access to cultural heritage funding. Because this is what we're going to give her the recognition she deserves.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Supporting our common European heritage is a fundamental task that plays a decisive role in shaping our future. Learning about and learning about our cultural heritage is a future that feeds on the past and is a common treasure of all of us. However, there are communities for whom the preservation and transfer of their mother tongue, cultural goods, demands sacrifice every day, despite the fact that they have enriched Europe with their language and traditions for centuries. I am thinking of national minorities and language groups. We have very encouragingly finished the last year with a successful debate and resolution on the Minority Safe Pack European Citizens' Initiative in the European Parliament. I also see today's debate as some kind of continuation of this, and there has been a new development since then. On Thursday, the European Commission gave a essentially dismissive response to the Minority Safe Pack initiative, and in doing so the Commission once again missed a great opportunity to take measures to show its commitment to indigenous minorities in Europe, to support and protect their culture. He practically turned his back on these people. The role of cultural heritage in taking on and promoting diversity, cohesion, solidarity and understanding is invaluable. That is what our draft decision reads. The only answer we need now is when the Commission takes this seriously.

name: Radka MAXOVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if this time has taught us anything, it is that nothing is self-evident. This is doubly true for culture and cultural heritage. The year 2018 was declared the Year of Cultural Heritage. The events held this year attracted almost 13 million participants. This only proves how important our cultural heritage is and that there is a great deal of interest in it among European citizens. However, this must not end in 2018. In order to achieve this objective and continue this action, we need better policy coordination and cultural heritage funding. Here I would expect the European Commission not to forget culture. It is therefore very unfortunate that the Commission is not working on culture in its work programme for 2021. Digitalisation, in particular, has enormous potential for cultural heritage, which we must exploit. Especially at a time when physical visits to cultural institutions are not possible, it shows how important and beneficial digitalisation is for all of us.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Europe's intellectual and material cultural heritage is a defining element and source of our identity. Therefore, the Union must put this protection into practice. It called on the European Commission to do so through a European citizens' initiative to protect 1.1 million citizens, such as minority safe pack national minorities. Unfortunately, instead of taking the request of its citizens seriously and thereby bringsd the Union to them, the Commission decided not to initiate a legislative process to protect traditional national and linguistic minorities. Yet European languages are on the verge of extinction, our traditional cultural riches.  The real equality of opportunity for 50 million European citizens is at risk. For this reason, we will send a letter to the President and Vice-President of the Commission with the minority intergroup in connection with the negative reply. As stated in the report that is being debated, there is a need to protect the cultural heritage of Europe's traditional national minorities through coordinated measures. The same is the case with the protection of our Christian cultural values. According to one survey, four out of five EU citizens believe that the protection of religious buildings is essential. Despite this, hundreds of buildings are being destroyed before our eyes. Memorials with roots become victims of vandalism. Europe can only remain truly strong if it is made up of strong nations with strong identities and roots. The lack of protection and surrender of our cultural heritage leads to a lack and surrender of our identity.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Mr President, 'not essential' is the expression with which culture has been condemned in France as in many of our countries. The coronavirus crisis, like any crisis, acted as a revelation and it showed what our societies, our leaders regarded as absolutely necessary or as absolutely superfluous. Not essential book and reading. For months, offices, supermarkets and tobacco remained open but bookstores were closed. Not essential theatres and cinemas. We can debate in this Chamber, fortunately, but the artists have no right to return to the stage. Not essential works, historical sites, the heritage of Europe. Would shopping malls be safer than the galleries in our museums that are 90% closed? More profitable, no doubt, for sure. As if the only basic needs were material, as if only immediate consumption was a vital emergency, all we learned about the civilization that made Europe is that real life begins with the life of the spirit and if we do not find the meaning of existence there, then why fight so much for the health of the bodies? The crisis we are experiencing threatens the already fragile life of our cultural fabric and strikes hard at those who are the soul: actors, musicians, guide lecturers, publishers, craftsmen, thousands of them have already been forced to change their profession today. With them, it is talents, promises, essential know-how that are at risk of being lost. What the European Heritage Year should serve to reaffirm is that we are Europe, the old continent, the one which, Steiner said, has its own character of being inhabited by its history and heritage. In fact, Europe now has to devote part of its budget to cultural heritage, it is not yet the case, it was a project for the European campaign, it is now an emergency if we want to open our eyes, it is the only real essential.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for this rich and interesting discussion. I have taken note of your contributions and will cherish them in my future work. They will be very useful for the Commission's work on this issue. Before I conclude, let me mention the difficult times we are currently experiencing. We all know that the European cultural heritage sector, including museums, heritage sites and other cultural heritage institutions, is seriously affected by the crisis. This is very well reflected in the report and I agree that these sectors need adequate financial support.  That's why we've innovated. In the summer of 2020, the Commission launched an extraordinary appeal on partnerships for creativity within the framework of Erasmus. EUR 100 million has been made available to support projects that develop skills and skills to encourage creativity.  We have also, with you, made the Creative Europe programme more flexible. We have launched specific industry actions and appeals. We have also ensured that the Union's horizontal measures to address the challenges of COVID can benefit the cultural sector. We have created specific platforms to give the industry the opportunity to exchange and create solutions.  Finally, we have maintained an ongoing dialogue with the cultural heritage sector and look forward to continuing to work closely with Member States to continue to find ways, solutions to mitigate the effects of the crisis, to look to the future together. Once again, I reiterate my strong support for the 2% of the recovery and resilience facility to be devoted to supporting this report. Today, we have new features. We have the Creative Europe programme, we have the Erasmus programme, we have, including within the framework of my portfolio, new developments such as the new culture cluster, we have a new community of innovation and communication with the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.  These are the elements from which we need to build new partnerships to build ecosystems. I also mention something we are not used to talking about, but three of the five new missions under the Horizon Europe programme have specific references and recommendations related to the cultural sector.  So today we have these programs, we have a strengthened budget thanks to you. It is now a question of building real synergies, of being able to finance this sector and help it, not only through programmes that we know but which are not sufficient. In this context, let me just mention that today, together with Commissioner Ferreira, we announced the launch of the design phase of the new 'European Bauhaus' project.  Today, we know that the green and blue transition will only be possible if we transform them into cultural projects that aim to involve all our fellow citizens and I obviously count here again on the sector of culture, cultural heritage, creation, so that we can truly build a bridge between the world of science and technology and that of art. , creativity, culture, unique resources that set us apart from the rest of the world, and that will enable us to transform, work and find solutions together. So I think we're all aware that there's still a lot of work to be done, but I'm sure it's only by working together that we can get out stronger and more united. Once again, you can count on me and the Commission as strong allies in this important area.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Tuesday, 19 January 2021, while the final vote will take place on Wednesday, 20 January 2021. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – 2018 was the European Year of Cultural Heritage, which proved to be a successful initiative. Cultural heritage is in itself a value, diverse, multi-layered (local, regional, national, European and global) and shaped (tangible, intellectual, natural, digital and digitised) that are interconnected. Cultural heritage promotes cultural and creative sectors both inside and outside Europe, the cultural heritage sector employs more than 300 000 people in Europe and 7.8 million jobs in Europe are indirectly linked to this sector. Languages enable and promote the richness and diversity of European cultural heritage, as mother tongues, often used to convey intangible cultural heritage, are carriers of values and knowledge. It is therefore essential to support European languages, which also play a prominent role in preserving our identity. It is regrettable that, although the report emphasises the importance of languages as part of cultural heritage and urges the Commission and the Member States to take greater steps to protect, develop and promote linguistic diversity, last week the European Commission swept up the Minority Safepack citizens' initiative. It is outrageous that the EU has repeatedly not stood up for national minorities and ignored the will of more than a million European citizens.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – Europe is the definition of culture and its primary task must be to protect Europe's religious and cultural heritage. The cultural and religious treasures of Cyprus are also a European heritage and I believe that the EU had and has a responsibility to protect it. It has been challenging, for 47 years, for the treasures of Cyprus to be destroyed and in the hands of the smugglers because of the Turkish Occupation. The EU must also take the initiative to protect the cultural heritage of occupied Cyprus, and to support the repatriation of the stolen cultural treasures of Cyprus. The preservation of cultural heritage in Cyprus is not only a matter for Cyprus but also for the EU itself.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. Today's debate is "about building a useful political legacy in the run-up to the European Year of Cultural Heritage."  We all agree that the culture and cultural heritage of our peoples and nations are treasures inherited from our past, and which bear witness to European history and traditions. These are our values that have their roots in Greek philosophy, Roman law, the Christian religion, the Renaissance and the Enlightenment.  A people that ignores its history is a people that does not know where it is going. We must strongly oppose this pseudo-culture from across the Atlantic, this "cancel culture" which, as the name suggests, wants to clean up all that constitutes our identity!  Already between 2002 and 2006, the question of Europe's Christian roots had been at the centre of the debate on the draft European Constitution, as supporters of Turkey's entry into the EU had tried to exclude this reference in the final text, winning the rest. It was a major historical and political mistake. Let us be keen today not to repeat it!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Alexandra Geese, Othmar Karas and Dragoș Pîslaru on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a technical support instrument (COM(2020)0409 – C9-0148/2020 – 2020/0103(COD)) (A9-0173/2020). I would like to remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  There are also plans to make remote interventions from Parliament's Liaison Offices in the Member States of choice.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I have the honour today to present a small European success story. The Technical Support Instrument (TSI) generates knowledge for Member States’ public administrations and it allows them to implement sustainable reforms and investments, drawing – with the help of the European Commission – on the best and tailor-made expertise available. So it is no coincidence that it enjoys strong support from all Member States. Thanks to a strong position of the European Parliament – and here I would like to thank my co-rapporteurs, Othmar Karas and Dragoș Pîslaru, for their excellent cooperation on this file – today we have a Technical Support Instrument that is substantially greener, more gender-equal and ensures stronger transparency. That is to say, it is more in line with today’s European priorities. First of all the European Green Deal, because knowledge about climate mainstreaming and climate tracking methodologies, for example, will help Member States to make their economies and their societies future—proof.  Strong transparency mechanisms will help to showcase the positive contribution of the European Union and foster pro—European attitudes, and more power to local and regional levels will enhance change from the bottom with the more direct involvement of citizens. So, we have many reasons to be proud of this new instrument.  But let me first explain what the Technical Support Instrument actually is. It supports Member States in their efforts to implement reforms and investments, giving them the institutional and administrative capacity they need. That means that Member States can simply ask the European Commission for help and the European Commission will either provide the expertise directly, or task experts to do so, working very closely with Member States. The TSI replaces the Structural Reform Support Programme, which has successfully supported over 1 000 reform projects in the 27 Member States since 2017. It has a budget of EUR 864 million for the period 2021—2027, and although it is a standalone instrument it will also assist the national authorities in implementing the recovery and resilience plans successfully.  As I mentioned at the beginning, the TSI is more than the continuation of a successful programme. It specifically addresses crucial challenges of our time – climate change and the European Green Deal – listing among the eligible actions, which are a sort of menu for the Member States to pick and choose from, methodologies for climate tracking. This is a crucial instrument, which we need in order to fulfil not only our climate goals, but also to raise awareness on local, regional and national levels to the many ways in which reducing CO2 emissions can also improve the life of citizens. For example by reducing air pollution in cities, which is something our citizens care about.  Then there is the resilience of our health care systems. We are still in the midst of the COVID—19 pandemic, which has demonstrated all too clearly how essential well—organised public health systems are. There is also the digitalisation of public services, upskilling policies in the labour market – we know how much change we will experience in the labour market in the next years – and the fight against poverty and income equality.  Then there is the last point, which is particularly close to my heart: gender equality. Because when we speak about competitivity and growth, we often forget one of the key factors to achieve sustainable growth, competitivity and more social justice at the same time, and that is gender equality. There is ample evidence that gender equality in the labour market is closely linked to economic growth. There is also ample evidence that women are currently paying the highest economic price for the COVID—19 crisis. So, in order to overcome this crisis successfully, we need to support gender equality. The right way to do this is to invest public funds equally between men and women. This is not easy, because it requires a good methodology and often even external expertise, and that is one reason why many administrations still shy away from it. Unfortunately, this has also been true for our European Commission, which shied away from gender impact assessments in the Recovery and Resilience Fund for that reason.  This is the reason why Parliament insisted on including expertise on gender budgeting and gender impact assessment among the eligible actions.  All administrations therefore have access to the best methods to determine what impact their measures and budgets have on women and men and how to promote a more gender—equal – and therefore more inclusive and more successful – society.  I am convinced that the Technical Support Instrument will make an important contribution to the socially inclusive, green and digital transition we urgently need in Europe.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, we started 2021 with optimism after one year of struggles, of sadness, of fear and insecurity. The COVID-19 pandemic changed our economy and society for the years to come. But now we see the light at the end of the tunnel and we now have the means to think about our future. Optimists understand that life can be bumpy and they learn from mistakes and failures in order to be prepared next time. Now it’s time for us to learn the lessons. I heard once an African proverb saying ‘if you want to go fast, go alone, if you want to go far, go together’. We aim here to go far in Europe and the truth is that we cannot continue as before, we need to help each other and stick together in an ever closer Union.  Member States unfortunately implemented only half of the recommendations that the Commission addressed to them in the European Semester. This means health systems only half prepared, social protection systems only half effective, economies half strong and sustainable. This means a future half bright for our next generation. The year 2021 comes with new challenges and we are to face them and we need to know how, and the technical support instrument will bring this help and knowledge to the Member States.  Together with my colleagues Othmar Karas from the PPE and Alexandra Geese from the Greens, with the other shadow rapporteurs, with the German Presidency and with the precious help from Commissioner Ferreira and her team, we have put forward a very thorough and comprehensive instrument which, through its capacity and size, can be seen as investment in the future with high European value added. The technical support instrument has a more challenging task than its predecessor, the structural reform support programme, and therefore has a larger budget: EUR 864 million worth of technical support is right now available for the Member States, and that’s for those Member States that wish to undergo long-term reforms and encourage public and private investment.  This instrument will prove essential if we aim to truly address the green and digital transitions, to achieve the Union’s 2030 climate and energy targets and climate neutrality by 2050. Member States can also receive assistance when designing digital infrastructure skills and the e—government solutions of building a secure digital communication system.  A stronger Europe, a stronger Union, is one that overcomes social divergence. For that the instrument helps Member States that wish to fight against poverty to promote entrepreneurship, labour market integration, lifelong learning and vocational education and ensure access to health care and child care. These measures are not possible without solid institutions and this is why Member States should use the Commission’s expertise to build capacity to better absorb EU funds, to build capacity of competition, and antitrust authorities then to strengthen financial supervision.  But before aiming to achieve convergence and resilience, we need to address our urgent demands. The most important role of the instrument lies in the recovery of EU Member States after the pandemic. Therefore, as part of the recovery package, this instrument will first and foremost be available to prepare, to amend, and to implement and revise the national plans the Member States will put forward to access recovery money under the recovery and resilience facility. It is highly recommended, and if we wish to have a sustainable and fair economic and social recovery, we need to use this instrument.  The pandemic showed how valuable our civil society is and there is no doubt that it has to be treated as a partner when implementing large scale reforms. Measures to empower civil society, as well as consultations with relevant stakeholders, are crucial and are particularly encouraged by this instrument. We also need to think more about gender equality since women have been hit especially hard by the consequences of this outbreak. The instrument will show expertise on gender budgeting, on collecting gender disaggregated data and providing gender-impact assessments.  This instrument will show a positive example of proper communication and transparency. Transparency promotes good governance and builds trust in the decision-making process. It is extremely important as a tool to prevent corruption and bad governance practices. I wish to assure you that all EU actors play their role in this instrument, including the European Parliament. This House will receive information on Member States’ requests and this information, as well as the outcomes of the support provided to the Member State, will also be published on the Commission website. We will look forward to receiving annual reports from the Commission and we will gladly welcome the Commission in this House to discuss about the implementation of this instrument.  We see governments leaving their citizens in crisis in a moment in which people truly rely on them. To them and to all Member States I wish to say, leave politics aside and please use this instrument. Use it to prepare your national recovery resilience plans in order to access the funds needed for reforms and investments. Use it to implement the measures listed in the plans and to recover. Use it afterwards until 2027 to create a sustainable and fair economic, social and gender-equal future beyond the pandemic. This way we will truly become more resilient for the upcoming challenges.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the last 12 months have highlighted the crucial role of public administrations and public services at all levels of government. In the roll—out of vaccines, support to businesses, digital solutions for work and schooling, public administrations have to adapt quickly and find the right tools and solutions that best serve their citizens. This is why the modernisation through reforms is so crucial for both the public and private sectors. Today we are discussing a powerful tool for supporting growth—enhanced reforms and for building better public administrations: the Technical Support Instrument. Reform support has come a long way in the last ten years, from crisis management to structural challenges, and from just two Member States to working with all Member States. In the past four years, we have supported more than 1 000 reform projects in a broad range of policy areas. Most importantly, these were nationally owned reforms, requested by Member States. With a results—oriented and hands—on approach, we have gained the confidence of Member States. But reform is never a goal in itself. Reform is a means to an end, a better environment for business, more resilient healthcare systems, better social and educational systems, better resilience to crisis and a smooth return to sustainable growth. Our method is Europe at its best. We aim to act as the catalyst bringing together Member States so they can help each other, sharing the expertise that is already there. We do so in respectful partnership with Member States.  This expertise is needed today more than ever in the recovery from COVID—19, in the transformation of our economies to prepare the green and digital transition, and in preparing and implementing the European Recovery and Resilience Facility. In fact, I would say that this instrument will be important for the success of the MFF and the Next Generation funds. The Recovery and Resilience Facility offers unprecedented support for reforms and investments, but will be a massive administrative challenge, a challenge requiring strong project management skills and robust administrative capacity.  With the Technical Support Instrument, we send a clear message to all Member States and regions: we stand by you, we will do what it takes to help you succeed, including when it comes to making the most of the Recovery and Resilience Facility. I can think of no better example than the spirit of Europe than standing together both in crisis and in good times, facing events such as this pandemic, and building our digital and green future. I thank the rapporteur and the co—rapporteurs for their work on this instrument, and not least for speeding up the legislative process to ensure we are ready to deliver support on the ground already by early spring. I look forward to our discussion.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs provided an opinion on this instrument that shows how its use is essential in truly implementing the European pillar of social rights in accomplishing the United Nations sustainable goals. On behalf of all my colleagues in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee that were hard in challenging conditions to provide our input, I wish to urge you to support the instrument as well as, you know, the Member States to use it in order to address the reforms needed in all key economic and societal areas.  We hope that it will be accessed with a view to creating quality jobs, education and training, that it will foster great ideas for the promotion of youth and children policies and will set up the framework for social protection policies that will focus on vulnerable groups. We hope that the Commission expertise will help the Member States to improve the capacity of public institutions to guarantee mobile and cross-border workers’ rights. Member States need social progress and the Technical Support Instrument (TSI) is a great tool to show how economic and social convergence can bridge.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner Gabriel, today we are discussing, for approval, the Technical Support Instrument, a programme with a budget of only EUR 864 million for twenty-seven countries and seven years, but with very high added value. Its predecessor, with only 220 million euros for three years, has been able to finance, as the Commissioner said before, more than a thousand projects in areas as different as the design of strategies for the protection of coasts or the development of telemedicine. And in this case, the new Instrument, with this strengthened budget, will allow Member States to continue to benefit from this specialised technical support, in addition to a context of greater need and therefore greater usefulness, as we are in the development of national programmes in the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism. From the negotiations with the Council, I would like to stress that we have managed to include among the objectives of this Instrument support for the development of budgets to achieve climate targets, the gender perspective and support for combating aggressive tax planning, fraud, evasion and tax avoidance. Special thanks to the three speakers for their fantastic work.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) is at the heart of the emergency NextGenerationEU programme, which the Commission is using to pretend that the EU is finally resilient. The recipe: "Ever Closer Union", that is, the cause of even the EU's permanent crisis. With the RRF, the EU is writing member states a debt-financed cheque for €672.5 billion, the advance reward for reforms, the European Semester, illegal debt community, non-contractual ECB bond purchases, zero interest rates and empty threats to force the Commission, reforms – that teach us ten years of experience – that will never come. Why? Because the EU slept through the outbreak of the crisis, this House prefers to debate the third sex, human rights on Borneo, climate rescue or interference with freedom of expression, rather than border closure, competitiveness or selective protection for particularly COVID-vulnerable people as an alternative to lockdowns and the Leyens Commission ordered too little vaccine, and in the midst of the crisis prefers to think of new Africa strategies and safe access routes for more corona-infected migrants. In the absence of a vaccine, death rates and debt are rising, but the economy is shrinking. The technical support instrument here is that the EU is now to support states in the preparation and implementation of the record expenditure. A further EUR 864 million for more bureaucracy and external consultants, because member states lack the expertise in the absence of reforms – despite ten years of promises of reform. Every day, the EU is more like an anti-authoritarian kindergarten for hard-to-educate children who are rewarded before they get better. NextGenerationEU is on the fastest path to secular stagnation – secular not for secular, but for the long term and probably all times.

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: for the Verts/ALE group. – Ladies and gentlemen, let me first say that the Technical Support Instrument is a perfect example for me of the scale of a small but possible impact of a fundamental European investment policy instrument. It is in all our interests that our states be more robust, effective and transparent through reforms. As we see painfully directly in the current crisis, public administration must be able to withstand shocks and crises. It must be able to provide citizens with quality services and have complete confidence in them. This can best be achieved through transparency. This is not only about time lost in office, but, unfortunately, as we can see, human lives may also be at stake as a result. Investing in reform support is thus clearly worthwhile. I am also very glad that, as Parliament, we have prepared high-quality material. Material that would introduce broad transparency and publication of the results and studies processed under the Technical Support Instrument. I see this as an absolute necessity for the instrument for supporting public administration reforms. Citizens have the right to know on the basis of what data, in cooperation with whom and why changes will take place in their state. I must express my disappointment that, in the trialogues, the Council has clearly opposed transparency. I also find this very unfortunate from the point of view of the nation states. Please take into account that the transparency of the state apparatus and the involvement of citizens in decisions are not a threat, but a way to manage common things more effectively.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, seven years after the troika adjustment programmes, the Technical Teams of the European Commission are back. My country knows them well. The last time we were governed according to the guidelines of these technical teams, the European Commission spared no praise to the right-wing government at the time. The result was the greatest economic recession and the greatest social catastrophe in the history of our democracy.  These teams recommended an even greater deregulation of the labour market, which triggered unemployment and also recommended unprecedented cuts in our National Health Service, which left it weakened to face the challenges it faces today.  They always say it's all very voluntary and now comes masked with beautiful intentions. But we've met this movie!  And so I suggest that the Commission leave its technicians in Brussels, give the money to the Member States and let those that European citizens have chosen govern, with the programmes that have been suffraged. It's called democracy.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, the agreement to implement this Technical Support Instrument is important, because in practice it is a key tool for dealing with the economic and social impact of the pandemic. On the substance, however, it allows the Commission to continue to provide expertise to member states in order to improve their capacity to develop and implement reforms and investments, within their own plans and in the context of the recovery and resilience of the relevant mechanism.  As a political group we have managed to introduce many of our priorities, such as the social pillar, the involvement of the social partners and much more. However, I would also like to stress this: in addition to health, job growth, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, research and innovation, the promotion of sustainable investment, we finally end up with the role that the Commission itself should play. The Commission itself should provide flexibility by encouraging Member States to choose reforms and investments that meet their own needs.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, now that we are finally completing the legislative framework for the European Recovery Fund, we have before us a double challenge: firstly, to heal as soon as possible the wounds of the great recession caused by the pandemic, to speed up the adoption of national plans, to start immediately the disbursement of European Recovery Fund funds in order to support employment, the socially weaker and the middle class. At the same time, as the pandemic continues, we must find European solutions to regulate and alleviate the increased public debt caused by the recession and pandemic and accelerate mass vaccination and faster vaccine production, because if we do not permanently tame the pandemic, the economy will not recover.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have taken good note of the points you have made: reinforced budgets, concrete projects with real added value, the importance of the instrument for the recovery, the importance of women.  All of these aspects are very important and I would really like to thank you, but I would like to close with a reminder that we need flexible, high—quality public administrations that are quick to introduce digital services, such as e—health and digital education, and administrations that are better at designing and implementing business support – administrations that pave the way to recovery with strong green and digital agendas, administrations that are modern and ahead of the game. Divergence in administrative capacity means divergence in recovery. The technical support instrument is the cohesion policy of public administration, building administrative capacity and implementing growth—enhancing reforms so that no Member State or any European is left behind.  Thank you for this discussion today and several times this past year. I have been encouraged by the speed of the co—legislators and the support of this Chamber. Let us all keep up the good work!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 19 January 2021. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Writing. – This week, we are taking another step towards reviving the largest EU investment programme of all time. The so-called 'technical assistance instrument' – which we will adopt tomorrow – is much more than its name suggests at first sight: it is an essential wheel in the gears of 'NextGenerationEU', which assists Member States in future projects, supports the planning, implementation and revision of the reconstruction plans and encourages urgent reforms and investments. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks for the excellent cooperation: to my two co-rapporteurs, as well as to the entire negotiating team, the Commission and the German EU Presidency. We have pulled together across institutions, committees and factions in order to make the already successful precursor instrument even better.
