We are putting the 'technical assistance instrument' at the service of our future by adapting the scope to our common challenges. We support the implementation of the European Semester with a clear link to the country-specific recommendations. We strengthen democratic control with regular implementation reports and hearings in the European Parliament. We increase transparency with a public online register. We improve visibility with joint communication activities. We are expanding flexibility by enabling additional national budget contributions. And we are stepping up the enforcement of the rule of law.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. As has been said so many times, the global crisis caused by the coronavirus must be responded to at EU level by common means. This is the motto of the Technical Support Instrument presented in the debate, which complements the €672.5 billion Recovery and Resilience Facility. This EU grant with a budget of EUR 864 million will ensure, first and fore for the economic and social recovery of the Member States and the strengthening of administrative capacities for the implementation of EU law. Throughout the negotiations, the European Parliament has advocated that the instrument should contribute to the implementation of the socially inclusive green and digital transition and to transparency in the allocation of EU funds. This instrument provides an opportunity for all EU Member States to set up a more predictable, resilient economic and health system for social interests after a 2020 year of uncertainty. However, it is up to the governments of the Member States to achieve this. One thing is certain, we in the European Parliament are fighting for closer integration, one of the great achievements of which is this new EU instrument, the Technical Assistance Instrument, which I hope will be used by all Member States to help citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Caroline Roose, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on more fish in the seas? Measures to promote the recovery of stocks above maximum sustainable yield (MSY), including fish stock recovery zones and marine protected areas (2019/2162(INI)) (A9-0264/2020). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  Remote intervention is also planned from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I am proud to be able to present this report to you today, on a subject that is particularly close to my heart. I am an ecologist, daughter and wife of a sailor and a friend of many fishermen in my area. While here, including in this Parliament, some are still trying to oppose fishing and the protection of fisheries and biodiversity, the fishermen I meet have understood that they depend on it. That is the central idea of my report. More fish in the seas means both achieving our environmental goals and protecting biodiversity. But it is also to allow fishermen to continue to fish in the long term. The year 2020 was to be the year when the European Union had to achieve the good environmental state of the seas and the year when all fish stocks had to be exploited at a sustainable level. Since the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy in 2013, real progress has been made but the targets are not being met and there is an urgent need.  The situation is very different in the Atlantic and Mediterranean areas. Some time ago, I met the fishermen in Brittany and Normandy. They explained to me that some species, such as the scallop, were doing very well but were seeing other phenomena such as a proliferation of sea spiders due to warming water and climate change. The situation in the Mediterranean is alarming. More than 80% of fish stocks are still overfished. So we have to go further. There is a need to strengthen scientific knowledge of fish populations, but also of interactions between different species. Selectivity, bycating bycating catches, framing and limiting the most destructive fishing techniques must be improved. All quotas must also be set transparently and never beyond scientific recommendations and levels to achieve sustainable maximum performance. I also proposed in this report to study the relevance of new indicators such as the ER (maximum economic return). It aims to fish below the level of the RMD (maximum sustainable yield). This would improve the resilience of fish populations and the economic viability of fisheries in the medium and long term. To prepare this report, I met with many stakeholders from the world of fisheries and environmental associations. I am lucky enough to live next to the sea, near several marine protected areas, including Cape Roux, in the Var. While a fisherman was showing me around the marine protected area, we saw a trawler coming to fish in the middle of this area.  His observation, I heard him repeat in the mouths of many fishermen and associations I met: many of the marine protected areas in Europe are protected only on paper: no monitoring, incomplete management plans when they exist... Using different methods, NGOs and scientists have come to the same conclusion: while we claim to have protected 10% of Europe's seas, less than 2% are actually protected. The biodiversity strategy sets a target of 30% of European waters being covered by marine protected areas with a high level of protection. This is an excellent thing that is consistent with the scientists' recommendations, but it will only be a large greenwashing operation if these protected areas do not have real management plans and controls. Fishermen's acceptance of marine protected areas is a key element of their success. All stakeholders must be involved in the establishment, management and monitoring of these marine protected areas, starting with fishermen and scientists. So we must also explain: 30% of marine protected areas does not mean that fishermen are excluded from 30% of maritime areas. In the 10% that will benefit from strong protections, there will have to be areas where all catches and economic activity is prohibited, but in the majority of protected areas, it is only the most destructive fishing techniques that must be limited according to local characteristics and seasonally.  There are examples. Very few fish population recovery zones have been established since their inception in 2014. However, there are areas for the replenishment of fish stocks, such as the "Jabuka/Pomo" set up in 2017 by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, which are already bearing fruit. Placed in a strategic location where certain species breed, including hake, it has allowed the reconstruction of populations of this species, visible beyond protected area and won the support of local fishermen. Let us draw on this for all marine protected areas. Fish populations also face climate change and various sources of pollution, such as wastewater treatment, the use of pesticides in agriculture, cigarette butts thrown into or from beaches, sunscreens, etc. We need to study these phenomena better in order to act afterwards. It is also important that the resources of the future FEAMP be mobilised towards objectives that I have cited: the creation of these high-level marine protected areas, the management and control of them, research on selectivity, the training of stakeholders, such as jurors. I call on the Commission to take up this report for the implementation of the biodiversity strategy, which must be translated into binding legal texts, for the action plan for the conservation of fisheries resources and the protection of marine ecosystems that you have announced for this year and for the evaluation of the common fisheries policy, also in the coming months. I wanted to conclude by thanking my various fellow shadow rapporteurs whose spirit of compromise has enabled us to have a full report. I was pleased to work with you on this report, even though the negotiations took place mainly through our teams. Thank you to the NGOs, to the fishermen who helped me with this report. Let us continue this work for nature, for fishermen and for there to be more fish in the seas.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Roose, and the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) for bringing forward this important own—initiative report on more fish in the sea. Yes, more fish in the sea is what we all want and what this planet needs. Our fishermen and women, who go to sea every day to supply us with healthy food from the ocean, are the first to benefit from more fish in the waters, but abundant life in the ocean also plays a crucial role in our fight against climate change. The ocean has absorbed more than 90% of human—generated heat in the last century. It will only keep its ability to protect us if its ecosystems are healthy and rich, with lots of fish in its waters. I also welcome most of the findings of this report. They support the Commission’s approach under the European Green Deal, the Biodiversity Strategy for 2030 and the common fisheries policy. In the past decade, we have achieved significant progress to increase fish stocks in the North—East Atlantic, where the rate of fishing is on average already close to the maximum sustainable yield. However, we are still confronted with overfishing in the Mediterranean Basin. We are starting to make progress there too, with the multiannual plan for demersal stocks in the western Mediterranean and with many measures adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, mostly proposed by the EU. Our immediate priority is to build further on that success. In order to further move towards more sustainable fishing in all sea basins, I agree with the report that we need to improve our fisheries management to end overfishing. We need to expand our network of marine protected areas, improve their management and tackle other environmental factors beyond fishing that threaten our fish stocks. When speaking about improving our fisheries management, I fully agree that more data collection is necessary in order to assess the health of our stocks and monitor bycatches of sensitive species like harbour porpoise and dolphins. Bycatch must be eliminated or, where this is not possible, minimised so as not to threaten species conservation status. We need to do everything to better protect sensitive species and sensitive habitats. This is clearly required by the Technical Measures Regulation. The Commission will present, later this year, a report on the implementation of this Regulation and, as announced in the Biodiversity Strategy, an action plan to conserve fishery resources and protect marine ecosystems, which we announced in the Biodiversity Strategy and for which the roadmap will be published very shortly. I agree with the report that we need more sea areas covered by marine protected areas with a more efficient management and control system in order to deliver in the interest of our fishermen and women and to protect marine biodiversity. I hope that the final report, as it will be voted on Thursday, will keep this high level of ambition in terms of sustainable fishing and healthy fish stocks. Regarding the use of the maximum economic yield advocated in the report, I am more cautious. At this stage, the priority is reaching maximum sustainable yield for all stocks, which is also the agreed legal objective of our current common fisheries policy.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, how can we not share this objective, Commissioner, as Mrs Roose's report wants? A few weeks ago, I went to Mayotte and Reunion to meet the fishermen who have been criss-crossing these tropical waters for generations, and I would like to speak here for their concern: we have never seen such fragile marine species. Of the four tuna species in the Indian Ocean, only one was on alert only five years ago. Today, only one is out of danger. Stocks of all other species are collapsing, so there is an urgent need to respond. The first priority is to find the path of a reasoned fishing, controlled and respectful of the environment, as well as the wisdom inherited from its own tradition. Fishing is a wonderful relationship with the balance of life and not with a material available indefinitely. Innovation and technology must enable us to extend this legacy and pass it on.  Let's be clear, the drifting fish concentration devices that have multiplied in recent years have had a major impact on species survival. They divert marine migration, trap younger fish, multiply collateral catches and contribute to sea pollution. Together, we must find the path of shared responsibility with all stakeholders. Secondly, it is imperative that the European Union accept clear and respected common rules by its partners. We must put all our weight together to get out of the denial in which many third countries still persist, which can only lead to disaster. We will only achieve this with real firmness by requiring regular checks such as those practised today on European fisheries.  Finally, we need to improve the knowledge of these species through an ever-increasing investment in science, with the support of fishermen. We are not among those who believe that fishing is a way of delinquency against the sea, it is only with fishermen, the first explorers of the oceans, that we will be able to better know and preserve species and biodiversity.

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group- Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking Mrs Roose for her work. I believe that we have reached a balanced report which contributes to improving the sustainability of the exploitation of the seas. I reinforce here the challenge to the Commission, the Member States and the scientific community to the need to find a scientific model that best suits the management and exploitation of multi-specific fisheries. It will be an important development that could contribute to the more sustainable exploitation of fishing resources, with environmental but also social and economic gains for the sector.  I advocate the use of marine protected areas as an essential tool in the protection, management and recovery of marine habitats and species. For this tool to fulfil its purpose, it is necessary to ensure that it works through good governance based on the best available scientific knowledge with constant monitoring and effective control. In the implementation and management of marine protected areas, it is essential that all stakeholders are involved and, in this sense, strengthening that, since the beginning of the establishment of any marine protected area, professional fishing, recreational fishing, as well as all other sectors of commercial and recreational activity and the populations of the surrounding areas should be called to the process.  Marine protected areas are not incompatible with the existence of some more selective fishing activities and with fewer negative impacts on the existing environment or resources. We must, once and for all, combat, demystify this idea, whether among the members of this Parliament or with the fishing communities, because only in this way will we be able to implement the changes so relevant and necessary for the protection, recovery and resilience of the habitats and biodiversity of the European sea. I will end by declaring that I advocate the implementation of ambitious targets for the percentage of marine areas to be protected, as advocated in the Biodiversity Strategy for 2030.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, welcome Commissioner Sinkevičius and well done to Caroline Roose for an excellent report. There’s a simple logic to the message I’d like to share with you today. It’s if we keep on taking fish out of our seas at the current rates, without giving them a chance to rest and reproduce, our sea beds will become barren waste grounds sapped of marine life, and a wonderful source of food and employment. Protecting 30% of our waters should be legally binding by 2030 as recommended in the biodiversity strategy. We need more fish in our seas, not less. The EU committed to end over-fishing by 2020 - clearly, this has not happened. It is possible to implement measures that will allow for effective management of marine protected areas where fish will be given space to thrive. It is possible to do this whilst supporting sustainable fishing communities. Using improved fishing methods and monitoring and further improvements around meeting the basic targets set out by the Common Fisheries Policy and the Marine Strategy Framework Directive, we can and we must halt this decline. This crisis is made more urgent now with the complexities of ‘live’ Brexit. Over-fishing is a human-made problem but with a comprehensive and committed rebuild and restore strategy, we humans can be the solution. We can have more fish in the sea.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, fortunately, a lot of fish stocks are doing quite well. Sustainable management based on the maximum sustainable yield (MDO) is beginning to bear fruit, especially in the North Sea. However, overfishing remains a problem, particularly in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean. That is why it is important that we get as many species as possible at the MDO level. We rightly stress in this initiative report that this important measure must remain the starting point for file management, and that we should therefore not switch to other methods.  Fortunately, the report's initially indiscriminate criticism of ground-based fisheries has been removed, and quite rightly so. After all, we should not be guided by emotion, but based on facts. That is precisely why, Mr President, selective pulse technology must also be made possible within responsible frameworks.  More customization is also needed. After all, the differences between the various sea basins are very large. That is why I think it is very unwise to support the proposal to establish 30% of the sea everywhere as a protected maritime area, especially since no impact assessments have been carried out at all. I think that the rapporteur frankly expects too much from protected and closed nature reserves.  Let us not forget that fishing also simply needs space and is vital, not only for the fishing communities, but also for our food security.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I was recently contacted by scallop fishermen and processors from Kilmore Quay in Duncannon  in Wexford in Ireland about changes to landing rules in the UK due to Brexit. The Irish scallop fleet consists of just seven scallop boats from these two small coastal communities. The new requirements that have to be issued by UK centres from this month and then the complete ban on EU scallop boats landing at UK ports from April will destroy these businesses if we can’t find a solution.  The Brexit deal is bad for the Irish fleet. However, the 2020 economic report on the EU fishing fleet shows once again that the main driver affecting the economic performances of the EU fleet is the health of fish stocks. Why, then, does the EU want to continue to promote overfishing by reintroducing harmful subsidies in the new European Maritime and Fishery Fund?  We need to do more to support small-scale low-impact fishing and end harmful capacity-enhancing subsidies. Coastal communities in Ireland are worried that the EU may bring back subsidies that are harmful and ones that were removed before, and they fear that they will favour the supertrawlers who do the damage. Please, Commissioner, look after them.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is very curious that two years before the Commission reviews the functioning of the common fisheries policy, without giving time to rigorously assess whether or not decisions are effective, whether or not there are groups proposing revolutionary and sophisticated objectives, clearly dissociating the legislation from reality.  If we legislate without a solid foundation, without scientific criteria and without discussing it with the actors involved, we will have failed. And that's what's happening right now. We have not yet fully implemented the concept of 'maximum sustainable performance', and there are already those who want to change it to 'maximum economic performance', without any scientific basis. Protecting is fine. I strongly support him. I am not against marine protected areas, but we distinguish between tools and objectives. Marine protected areas are a tool and not a target. Activities in an area cannot be limited without pre-evaluating the conservation objectives of that area and its consequences. Nor can certain fishing arts and techniques be criminalized a priori. It's enough to demonize the fishermen. It's enough to accuse them of being the cause of all evil. Fishermen are the greatest protectors of the seas and biodiversity, and not some politicians and radicals who only look in one direction. We all want more fish at sea and, therefore, the main proposals in this text need a thorough revision.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It was our green colleague, Isabella Lövin, who laid the foundations for the then new fisheries policy here in the EU in 2013. Very, very important work and many thanks like this in arrears to you Isabella for it.  But now we have to take several important major steps forward. We really must protect 30% of the EU's maritime areas against overexploitation and depletion. We must also ensure that fishing quotas are based on what ecosystem services can deliver, that they are real sustainable and not anything else. And then we really need to put an end to the harmful, purely harmful fishing methods, such as the bottom trawling, which causes enormous damage to plants and animals and entire ecosystems on the seabed.  What's the solution to this? In fact, it is focusing on local, small-scale, coastal fishing. It not only provides healthier seas, but also an opportunity for new jobs in often smaller coastal resorts, and it also makes a contribution to a long-term sustainable rural area.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the interest of this House for the very important issues of sustainable fisheries and marine environmental protection and I have carefully listened to your interventions. And yes, I cannot stress it often enough as Ms Carvalhais stated, that strengthening scientific coverage and control will be key. Replying to Mr Ruissen and Mato, as regards the concept of maximum economic health, I’ve already mentioned it in my introductory remarks that our first ambition of course should be to properly implement the maximum sustainable yield, which is at the moment our current legal obligation and of course top priority.  And let me say that I particularly welcome also the involvement of the members of the Environment Committee in this debate The issue we discussed tonight is so cross-cutting that we need to ensure close cooperation between fisheries and environmental communities experts to ensure the necessary coherence and credibility of our actions and policies. Apart from a lot of support and ambition, I also heard some of you raising concerns in particular about having 30% of Europe’s seas covered by marine protected areas, of which 10% will be strictly protected. Let me reassure you that I fully understand that you want to ensure that our fishermen and women can fully benefit from marine resources, in particular in the current economic context of the global pandemic and the challenges several Member States face in the aftermath of Brexit. And let me be very clear, so do I.  However, it is precisely our fishermen who will be the first to benefit from more abundant fish stocks in the areas around those marine protected areas. There are very concrete success stories of fishermen and women with increased income around well-functioning MPAs, such as the Columbretes area in Spain, the Torre Guaceto area in Italy and the Jabuka/Pomo Pit in the Adriatic Sea. These positive examples should encourage us all. Honourable Members, I hope that the final report as it will be voted on Thursday will underpin our common efforts under the European Green Deal and the biodiversity strategy for 2030, in line with the resolutions of the European Parliament of January 2020 on the European Green Deal and on the 15th Conference of Parties of the Convention on Biological Biodiversity. All the issues raised in this report will be very valuable input for the preparation of our report on the implementation of the common fisheries policy, due too for the end of 2022, as well as for the first report on the technical measures regulation and for the action plan to conserve fishery resources and protect marine ecosystems, as announced at biodiversity strategy for 2030.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union makes it clear that animals are sentient beings. This fact must therefore be taken into account in the formulation and implementation of Union policies, m.in. the Union's agricultural, fisheries and transport policies. The presence of such legislation in one of the legal acts laying down the basis for the functioning of the EU would make it possible to assume that the protection of animals from suffering is among the Community's priorities. Unfortunately, the legal protection of animals, including farmed animals, in the European Union still leaves much to be desired, and fish and other aquatic animals are perhaps the most glaring example of this. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have emphasised the need for appropriate standards of legal protection covering all animals, including aquatic animals. I therefore supported the amendments prepared by the GUE, which highlight the need to regulate such fundamental issues as more humane methods of catching and killing fish. We also call for legal protection for marine invertebrates, including crabs and lobster, which are now still widely prepared for consumption by throwing live animals into boiling water. If the EU's ambition to improve the welfare of farm animals is not merely an empty declaration, the changes must address the situation of all animals, including those that have hitherto been frequently and unjustifiably overlooked, namely aquatic animals.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Marie-Pierre Vedrenne, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No. Regulation (EC) No 654/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the exercise of Union rights for the application and enforcement of international trade rules (COM(2019)0623 – C9-0197/2019 – 2019/0273(COD)) (A9-0133/2020). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  Remote intervention is also planned from the European Parliament's Liaison Offices in the Member States.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow the report on the application of trade rules is subject to your approval. Tomorrow, with its adoption, you will carry the voice of a more credible, effective and ambitious Europe. Tomorrow, with the amendment of this regulation, you will meet the expectations of our businesses, our citizens for a Europe that asserts itself and protects itself. Tomorrow, by this vote, you allow Europe to send a message to its partners, the rules exist and they must be respected.  Power relations, clashes, trade tensions, it is in this geopolitical context of economic rivalry that Europe must register, with a global trade watchdog faltering. For just over a year, in December 2019, the appeals body of the World Trade Organization has had only one judge. In the face of the U.S. refusal to appoint new members, the dispute settlement system is paralyzed.  Faced with this deadlock, we could not stand still without action and the revision of the regulation, together with the Commission's original proposal, was therefore welcome. The Council quickly agreed, establishing a form of status quo. We, as parliamentarians, have understood the importance of this review. Bold and determined, with a clear mandate, we have managed to go beyond that. Colleagues, this vote also represents the voice of a United Parliament at the service of Europe that is gaining credibility, efficiency and ambition. Anna-Michelle, Berndt, Reinhard, Emmanouil, Helmut, thank you for your trust and for your joint work. Together, we have carried in the negotiations the urgent need to strengthen our trade policy, pressing it to defend our European interests, the imperative to strengthen our legal arsenal. Thus, with your vote, ladies and gentlemen, further progress will emerge. Let me go into the details. To be able to react, we must first give ourselves the means and have sufficient levers of action in the face of states that are taking the path of unilateral and illegal behaviour. By broadening the scope of our counter-measures, it is therefore the efficiency for Europe that is proposed.  In a world where the share of services and intellectual property rights is growing, the European Parliament has therefore convinced the Council to open up the possibility for the European Union to take action not only in the area of services and public procurement, but also in the services and intellectual property rights sector harmonised at European level. And we have met in a year's time, with an explicit revision clause to extend the scope to all intellectual property rights.  Commissioner, you have committed and willing Members in front of you and we expect much more. So, in the face of our determination to introduce interim and immediate measures against the manifestly illegal and unilateral actions of a trading partner, the Commission seems to have heard our appeal. You have pledged to present a new instrument to deter and counter coercive measures by third countries as soon as possible and by the end of 2021.  Commissioner, there is an urgent need. Commissioner, there is an obligation for the European Union to have such a deterrent to respond to behaviour that does not need to be. It is not a question of launching a trade war, simply of ensuring compliance with international rules and asserting itself as a trading power. Colleagues, in this institutional agreement, the three institutions, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have committed themselves with a joint declaration and I very much hope that we will not have to wait until the end of the year for the Commission to come up with a proposal. Immediate response to measures that do not comply with international law is essential, it is an issue of credibility.  With the arrival of Joe Biden as President of the United States, many imagine that we are immune to the unfounded measures that Donald Trump has accustomed us to. On the American side, perhaps. But the extraterritorial effects of their laws will certainly remain. On the other hand, other states are not left behind and we would make a mistake to wait. Our toolbox has few screwdrivers or wrenches. It is high time to complete it and it is high time to have all these keys that will allow us to open more doors. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we know all the issues relating to sustainable development provisions in our agreements. Commissioner, the Commission is committed to dealing with the EU's trade compliance official and the new single entry point, all violations of labour law, climate change and human rights at the same level as market access complaints. As you know, we want new concrete proposals so that the commitments that are included in our trade agreements are not just declarations of intent and are actually respected and implemented. Tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that Europe must continue to support the multilateral system and WTO rules unabated. With this report, we demonstrate that we are fully mobilized to combine discourse and action. Tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen, with the update of the regulation on compliance with the rules on trade, it is therefore the choice of efficiency, credibility, ambition, the choice of our strategic autonomy. Once again, I thank all my fellow shadow rapporteurs, the German Presidency and Vice-President Dombrovskis. When we are united, we know how to move Europe forward.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission expresses its gratitude to Parliament and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and its Chair, rapporteur Ms Marie—Pierre Vedrenne and all shadow rapporteurs for the constructive work and attention that went into this file and for the commitment shown to a swift adoption. The Commission regards this amendment as both important and necessary. Given today’s realities, there are two reasons for this. First, since December 2019 we no longer have an impartial and binding two—step adjudication mechanism within the WTO. This is of major concern for the European Union’s economic interests. To recall, this happened because of the Appellate Body of the WTO; the second tier of adjudication is unable to function due to the blockage of appointments by certain WTO Members. As you know, the Commission is sparing no effort in resolving the crisis. We have improved the situation in Geneva through the multi-party interim appeal arrangement, or MPIA for short, but it will not apply in all cases. The MPIA does not engage the entirety of the WTO Membership, far from it, and it is voluntary. In other words, WTO Members need to agree to its use in their cases with the EU. Therefore, as you have recognised, it is wrong to think that the danger arising from the breakdown of the WTO dispute settlement has passed. This underlines the importance of the legislative file you are voting on tomorrow. Next to our ongoing efforts to resolve the crisis, the amended Enforcement Regulation would enable the Union to protect its interests in the face of blocked dispute settlement systems. The Union would be able to take measures where it prevails in an offensive dispute against another country at the panel stage, but it’s unable to obtain a binding award because the other country blocks the process. Thus, the revised Enforcement Regulation will act as a line of defence, while at the same time it would act as a deterrent and an incentive for others to cooperate. Similarly, under the EU’s free trade agreements, there is no guarantee that a contracting partner will, in all cases, allow the proper functioning of dispute settlement. In the bilateral context, dispute settlement requires a certain degree of cooperation. The amendment would play a particularly important deterrence role for parties that might otherwise contemplate obstructing the proper functioning of dispute settlement. By concluding this file, we send a powerful signal to our trade partners. The Union is able to equip itself quickly and is ready to protect its rights, if a need arises. This is very important for the credibility of the Union’s enforcement action and for its timeliness, which is ultimately what our stakeholders will judge us on. Second, the importance of the amendment also lays in the broadening of possible remedies to cover trade in services and some trade—related aspects of intellectual property rights. The extension will allow the Union to make use of these additional possibilities whenever it is necessary for the effectiveness of the enforcement action or because the rules require it. The extension of scope results from a proposal advanced by Parliament. The Commission welcomes this improvement.  The extension unquestionably renders the Union’s enforcement action more effective and in line with today’s realities. It corresponds to the needs of modern and knowledge—based economies. It matches the prominence of services and intellectual property rights in international trade agreements. It makes the Union credible when it seeks to negotiate protection for the right holders abroad. It means the Union is serious about its agreements and obligation and will expect that partner countries stick to their commitments. And finally, broadening the scope increases the deterrence effect. Even though the extension is only partial in the field of trade—related aspects of intellectual property rights, we should not lose sight of the immense benefits of the extension in its current form. The Union is clearly better equipped than ever. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, the adoption of the revised enforcement regulation is really a step forward for the European Union. Now, we are able to defend the Union's commercial interests and rights, even when our partners are obstructing the dispute settlement mechanism either within the WTO or bilateral treaties. In addition, the scope of possible countermeasures to services is extended, which was a constant request of both the EPP Group and the majority of Parliament.  However, the European Commission should become both faster and bolder in exercising its rights to apply and enforce international trade rules, especially when faced with trading partners who have a long history of non-compliance with international rules, such as Turkey, which, for years, by unilaterally applying tariffs and equivalent measures, has been in breach of the provisions of our bilateral trade framework. At the same time, it continues the challenges in the Eastern Mediterranean, the violation of the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus, so I ask: can the European Union really trust a partner that does not respect international law? Despite Turkey's recent attack on Europe, I have serious doubts about its intentions. Both the Council and Parliament have called on Turkey to comply with international law. So with today's revision of the enforcement regulation, we are giving the European Commission another tool to enforce compliance with international law in Turkey.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, I thank Marie-Pierre Vedrenne for her report and begin by reiterating the European Parliament's full support for the rules-based multilateral trading system and, unequivocally, the WTO and its reform. However, in the face of the paralysis of the aide body of the WTO dispute settlement mechanism, the European Union acted swiftly to overcome the shortcomings of European legislation and to ensure the capacity to protect the interests of the Union and the Member States in the framework of international trade agreements.  Parliament wanted more and went further. We have extended the scope of the Regulation by including services and intellectual property rights in the list of EU trade policy measures. One and the other represent an important and growing part of trade on a global scale. This strengthens the credibility and deterrent effect of the Regulation and the European Union can also take action in these areas as quickly and effectively as in others, such as goods or public procurement. Parliament was also successful in obtaining a joint statement on the urgency of a new instrument to deter and counter coercive actions by third countries. Finally, I stress, not least, the commitment that this Regulation should ensure the more coherent application of the mechanism in trade disputes relating to international trade agreements, covering the chapter of trade and sustainable development.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Commerce connects the world. Never has trade been as extensive as it is today. Some of the EU's most important tasks are to work towards free world trade, governed by rules, where agreements are actually also held. It is only then that trade becomes a real tool for both economic growth and for promoting human rights and protecting the climate and the environment. It is therefore unacceptable that some countries are exploiting shortcomings in the structure of the WTO in order to avoid complying with contractual obligations.  With this decision, we are closing loopholes. It is a clear victory for Parliament. The EU will be able to take countermeasures. Not only in the area of trade in goods, but also in terms of services and certain intellectual property rights. The Commission has now also promised to propose, by the end of this year, an effective new instrument to deter and counter coercive measures by third countries. In addition, the Commission has promised to develop an improved supervisory system for our ftas to give equal importance to breaches of sustainability-related rules, as to breaches of market access rules.  There is a lot going on and we have high expectations. We are looking forward to ambitious proposals that will make it possible to fully maintain the chapters on sustainability in our trade agreements. This is extremely important for world trade. The EU has a unique opportunity here, together with its allies, to achieve results and drive change that may have an impact on better trade and for people's working conditions and our planet.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report "Power comes from the barrels of guns" – that is a saying of the Great Chairman Mao, and thank God we have moved on. Our companies, which generate wealth, create jobs, are dependent on foreign trade. Foreign trade creates prosperity. Without division of labour, without trade in raw materials and materials, and the worldwide provision of services, everything that we take for granted is not possible. That is why we need rules that are respected, and these rules must apply equally to everyone – to small and medium-sized enterprises as well as to large companies. And power must come from the legal norms, not from the barrels of guns. It must follow the performance and the agreed contracts. And that is why it is a proposal that we in this House, from the far left to the far right – with the interesting and regrettable exception of the Greens – can all support. As a peaceful trading nation, we want Europe, as a peaceful trading bloc, to ensure that our businesses can participate in the development of prosperity, and we want to give the same rights to those of other trading blocs. In this respect, we support this proposal and hope that as many colleagues as possible can join in so that our companies have legal certainty when they do what they are there to do, namely to maximise their profits – to the benefit of all stakeholders, shareholders, workers and also the community.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Let me begin by thanking the rapporteur, Marie-Pierre Vedrenne, and congratulating her for the hard work and good cooperation. As the EU, we need this new instrument, because we must be able to defend ourselves if other partners do not comply with international rules and then refuse to cooperate in dispute resolution. The Group of the Greens/European People's Party (EFA) will therefore vote in favour of this result. As you know, we had considerable reservations about the position originally adopted in this House, but a good compromise was reached in the trialogue. This does not stop work on better instruments for defending European values and interests against unfair trade practices. I look forward to working on making sustainability chapters in our trade agreements effectively enforceable, or on the Commission's proposals against WTO-related subsidies. Incidentally, I am pleased that the new Biden administration will be able to find a solution for revitalising the Appellate Body in dispute settlement procedures within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to like the Left Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Donald Trump has taught us that the European Union must be able to defend itself if trading partners do not follow the agreed rules. Congratulations to our rapporteur, Marie-Pierre Vedrenne. With the revised regulation, we are now giving the Commission a strong instrument for this. Please use it like a scalpel, not like a scythe in the rules-based multilateral trading world. In the negotiations, I worked to ensure that compliance with agreements on working conditions and rights and, finally, the protection of the climate and the environment, should now also be targeted by the Commission and, if necessary, enforced. In the future, it will be up to the first senior trade representative, Denis Redonnet, to actually investigate complaints. Stop cases of social and environmental dumping! One more lesson: it is best to have enforceable instruments in trade agreements, including in sustainability chapters.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the never-ending issue of American duties, first on steel and then on food, has clearly shown us how vulnerable we are to commercial blackmail, and this is totally unacceptable to our citizens and to our businesses. The regulation we are about to adopt will resolve this situation and will finally allow Europe to impose duties and sanctions against those who illegally penalise our exports. What we are going to vote on is a real bazooka, which will allow us to respond blow by blow to anyone who behaves incorrectly with us but above all will be a deterrent to all those countries that think they can harm our businesses and our excellence with impunity. In the past, European exports have been hit several times under their belts, but we will not allow this to happen again.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: – Mr President, with the amended Enforcement Regulation we are making sure that the EU can no longer be taken hostage through a deliberate obstruction of our legal avenues to resolve a trade dispute. Alongside the upcoming anti—coercion instrument, it should serve as a deterrent to those who would consider copying Trump—era tactics to run a process of reform into the ground. In this the EU will always observe the fullest respect for international law. By no means have we abandoned the track of reforming the WTO to return to a functioning Appellate Body. The day after tomorrow, the day after we vote this amended Regulation, a new US President takes office. Together we can find solutions to bridge our differences and together we can bring the WTO back to speed. Pour terminer, permettez-moi, Monsieur le Président, de remercier également Marie-Pierre Vedrenne pour son travail de qualité et pour sa ténacité lors des négociations.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – President and Commissioner, colleagues, because Donald Trump refused to appoint new judges to the World Trade Organisation in 2019, the highest arbitrator in international trade disputes was sidelined. And that was a huge problem because when states can no longer appeal when international trade agreements are not respected, we return to a time when only the law of the strongest applies.  Without rules, Europe is more vulnerable to dumping from the US, from China, and from countries elsewhere, and our companies face unfair competition from products that do not meet our social and environmental standards. If we do not put a dam against this, jobs in the entire Dutch economy are at risk.  I would like to thank the rapporteur and thank the Commission, because I can only welcome the fact that Europe now wants to change the rules and that, without the wto's crippled professional body, Europe will find a way to protect its trade interests.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Marie-Pierre Vedrenne, for her excellent work. The EU must remain committed to a multilateral order, an effective WTO and a functioning appellate body. But as the body remains paralysed, the EU needs to expand its enforcement possibilities, and this proposal we are discussing today will contribute to the next step in the expansion.  I especially welcome the equal treatment of breaches of market access and sustainable proficiency. The current proposal, however, is merely the beginning of expanding our trade toolbox. Developing enforcement capabilities for trade and sustainable development—related provisions in our FTA is the crucial next step. To achieve this goal, the EU must work towards developing strict enforcement instruments. We should act upon this opportunity that we have now. We need to develop an adequate and strict sanctions mechanism to make sure that trading partners respect the standards and FTAs we agreed upon. Our credibility and effectiveness in trade policy is at risk if we do not develop proper enforcement capabilities.  The Commission must show its commitment towards enforcing our standards to protect our values, to protect human rights. I strongly urge the Commission to come up with a proposal for an effective trade and sustainable development enforcement regulation, including an active role for parliamentary oversight.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam rapporteur Vedrenne, I have heard your enthusiasm. Above all, I think it must be said, better late than never.  It wasn't until Mr Trump blocked the WTO's appeals body that Europe decided to act. It's good, but it still took time. We are now taking appropriate action, this is just the beginning, we will be able to respond more quickly to tariff or quota aggression without waiting for the long wto dispute settlement procedure to take place. In this regard, I support the willingness of the Committee on International Trade to include in the new regulation the services and protection of intellectual property which, as you know, is being flouted at all times. But I still note a slight contradiction: you say that Europe will protect more and, at the same time, we sign an investment agreement with China. It is well known that China does not respect WTO rules, nor does it respect human rights. I note a slight contradiction and I think we will have to break with this systematic distortion between actions and words.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What a special day in the European Parliament! Twenty years ago, the Greens – or those who would be with the Left Party today – fought the World Trade Organization. And today, after Mr Bütikofer has now said that the Greens are still voting in favour, we are all arguing for us to be able to enforce the rules of multilateral world trade in the WTO in the future, even if others take us off the flag. I hope that you have learned and ihope that in future you will fight alongside us for multilateral world trade and trade agreements, even if we have not yet been able to convince you of them. It has already been mentioned that we may have a new chance for a new trade agreement with the new administration in the United States. The Greens in Germany – I hear Cem Özdemir, the member of the Bundestag – are in favour. Let us get on the road! The opportunity for Europeans in this century is to make the world a little better with multilateral trade agreements. For this, however, we need the Greens on board – please also in the future.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Trump's defeat in the US elections has made the world better, but it has not solved all the problems. We must now relaunch the transatlantic relationship, end the trade war and strengthen multilateralism by supporting the efforts of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres. One of the priority tasks is to reform the World Trade Organization and overcome the blockade on the appointment of judges that impedes the functioning of the dispute resolution system. Without an effective dispute resolution system, the European Union needs to find alternatives to protect its interests in the event of a breach of international rules. That is why I want to welcome the Commission's initiatives, first by launching a partnership with other countries for an alternative interim dispute resolution system, then by including trade sanctions in the recent agreement with the United Kingdom - finally, Commissioner - and now by presenting a proposal that allows, while respecting international law, to react more quickly and effectively to illegal trade practices. The European Union must continue to advocate multilateral solutions to global problems, but it must defend its interests. This means demanding respect for international trade rules.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, in recent years the European Union has witnessed an uncomfortable reality: the loss of relevance to the World Trade Organisation. Several are your threats, but I would highlight the paralysis of your Appellate Body.  We also attend with concern the breach or violation of the spirit of the commercial rules by those who do not respect the rules of the game. And, of course, the unfair unilateral tariff measures that affect European producers and, especially the Spaniards, and which we hope will be a priority in the relations of the European Commission and the new President of the United States of America.  The European Union has sufficient economic and political weight to protect its interests and rights in the commercial sphere, including services and intellectual property. This Regulation should help us to improve this capacity, as will the next anti-corruption mechanism that the European Commission has committed to present this year.  These are not easy times, but we must be ambitious. The European Union must promote and lead a viable reform of the WTO, promote its values and also its regulatory power.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their remarks. The Commission is thankful to the Parliament for recognising the vital importance and urgency of amending the regulation and for further strengthening the instrument.  The negotiations were swift and constructive, but they were also intense and demanding. They brought to light outstanding concerns and called for even stronger Union action. The Commission will thus continue the work, as agreed, to name two aspects for the forthcoming work. In a year’s time, the Commission will complete a review examining a possible further extension of remedies in the field of trade—related aspects of intellectual property rights. As already announced by President von der Leyen in her letter of intent of September 2020, the Commission will put forward a legislative proposal for an anti-coercion instrument to deter and offset coercive practices by third countries. As many of you mentioned this, let me give you a brief update. The instrument will be a new one and will seek to dissuade and offset coercive actions by third countries. The Commission will look particularly at the possibilities for expenditures responses. The Commission has commenced the preparatory work. The internal conceptual work is taking place, and the consultations activities with stakeholders will be taking place in the coming months. The Commission will share further details as soon as they become available. The Commission plans the legislative proposal for the last quarter of 2021, but is prepared to accelerate the proposal should the need indeed arise. To conclude, let me once again thank you for taking this important step forward. The European Union’s capacity for action is now stronger. We will continue to work together over the course of 2021 to do even more in this respect.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 19 January 2021.
